reviewText:
I liked "Kung Fu Panda," first for its look, second for its story, and I know that's usually not a good sign. I know that a film that puts style ahead of substance is by default less meaningful, and therefore not worth recommending. But that's being too harsh in this case; "Kung Fu Panda" is no more and no less than a family film with light-hearted subject matter, about as enjoyable as the average computer-animated film released this time of year. There's no question that the target audience is younger viewers, and indeed, there's plenty here visually for them to take in; not only is the art direction bold and vibrant, the physical comedy is plentiful, as well. As if martial arts never lent itself to comedy--this year alone saw the release of "The Forbidden Kingdom," a family-friendly Kung Fu fable that allowed us to laugh along with the story. "Kung Fu Panda" works in pretty much the same way, probably even better because it's an animated film.

Taking place in ancient China, we're immediately introduced to Po (voiced by Jack Black), a very overweight panda who runs a noodle stand with his bird father (voiced by James Hong). Unbeknownst to him, Po dreams of one day becoming a Kung Fu master, to be respected and adored by every animal living in the Valley of Peace. He wants to be as legendary as the Furious Five, Kung Fu disciples whose various animal styles reflect what they actually are (Viper practices viper-style, Crane practices crane-style, etc.). Po's humdrum life is changed when the elderly Kung Fu master--a turtle named Oogway (voiced by Randall Duk Kim)--chooses him as the next Dragon Warrior; it was during a temple ceremony that drew out the entire village, and Po barely managed to get there at all. The temple, you see, is located at the top of a very tall mountain, and the only way to get there is by climbing thousands of steps. Can you imagine how much energy a fat panda would need to do that?

Po's choosing comes as a shock to the Furious Five: Tigress (voiced by Angelina Jolie), Monkey (voiced by Jackie Chan), Mantis (voiced by Seth Rogen), Viper (voiced by Lucy Liu), and Crane (voiced by David Cross). Each is incredibly skilled in the ways of Kung Fu, yet an untrained, overweight panda has been chosen. No one is more upset about the situation than Shifu (voiced by Dustin Hoffman), who had been training the Furious Five for many years. He frantically appeals to Master Oogway, who can only speak in philosophical metaphors; the wise old turtle believes that absolutely nothing happens by accident, and you can never force the natural order of things, no matter how hard you try. Po will meet his destiny and become the next great Dragon Warrior only when Shifu decides to train him. That, of course, can only happen if he believes in him.

The thing is, Po initially doesn't believe in himself; despite his dream of being a Kung Fu master, he knows all too well that he's not ready for this, especially now that the other warriors hate him. The attempts at conventional training are disastrous until Shifu discovers Po's amazing ability to eat. Basically, his Kung Fu skills only emerge when he's after food. Po and Shifu eventually battle over a bowl of dumplings, and I don't think I've ever seen such lightening-fast chopstick maneuvers, in either an animated or a live action film. It gets the most intense when only one is left. Po unconsciously pushes himself to the limit when food is at stake, which isn't so far fetched since pandas are known to gorge themselves, especially in the spring months. Not that anyone will care about that--"Kung Fu Panda" is about comedy and special effects, not behavioral facts.

In the midst of all this training looms a dangerous threat: a ruthless leopard named Tai Lung (voiced by Ian McShane) has escaped from a maximum-security prison guarded by rhinos. He started out as Shifu's star pupil, but turned evil when Master Oogway refused to declare him the next Dragon Warrior. Now on the loose, Po discovers that only he can stop Tai Lung, meaning he must complete his training in a very short period of time. His final task is to open the Dragon Scroll, something that will supposedly tell him the secret to being the ultimate Kung Fu master.

If this sounds entertaining enough, that's because it is. It does not, however, transcend any recent computer-animated film, least of all in terms of story or characterization. A couple of things baffle the mind, like how it's possible for a tiny mantis or a snake or a crane to be a lethal Kung Fu warrior. And doesn't it make you wonder why Po's father is a bird? Near the end of the film, Po turns to him and says, "Sometimes I think I'm not even your son," so at least the filmmakers were well aware of what they were doing. Still, it seems a little too out of place, a little too unmindful of simple logistics like a panda being the offspring of other pandas. I did like the way the film looked, especially during some wide shots showing vast distances between fog-shrouded mountains. The film was projected on a seventy-millimeter screen, which was nice because the breathtaking landscapes weren't overcrowded, even when characters were present. "Kung Fu Panda" is definitely pretty looking, and while it doesn't tell a substantive story, there's enough there to keep you entertained all throughout.

Ok, I admit, I went to the theatre a bit negatively pre-biased.  Sure, the previews I saw were mildy funny and I do like Jack Black, but I thought Kung Fu Panda would be yet another vapid kids' animated movie with anthropomorphized animals saying cleverly planned puns and adultish in-jokes and that the funniest scenes were probably already shown in the trailer to draw audiences in.

I was very pleasantly surprised to be wrong.  Kung Fu Panda is hilarious and well-made, and though it is clearly aimed at kids, it was tremendously entertaining and satisfying for adults too.  The movie was pretty evenly funny throughout, with occasional uproarious hilarity, esp from Jack Black.  Like, have you ever gotten a comic image stuck in your head and you (embarrassingly) find yourself chuckling outloud, by yourself, for minutes after the audience stopped laughing?  Well, there were several moments like that in this movie for me.  There was a subtle, clever layer of humour particularly in some of the facial expressions, and I even found some of the side storylines genuinely touching, like the relationship between the son, a chubby panda (voiced by Jack Black) and the kind-hearted, noodle-shop owner father, a stork (voiced by James Hong).  The villain, a cloud leopard with sinister glowing eyes, is really menacing and scary (believe it or not), enough to scare some small kids into tears, so be forewarned.  The whole production, the "legendary" tale, authentic movements, and background sets really HONOR the Kung Fu movie tradition more than parody it, I thought.  I mean to say, the Kung Fu itself was pretty good (though it's animated and practiced by animals).  The animation was superb, and in particular, some of the food they showed was just mouth-watering (it really made us crave Chinese dumplings and noodles).  Lastly, I'd like to add that I went to the movie theatre without knowing who the voice cast was.  I only knew that Jack Black was in it.  Watching as the end credits rolled, we were just as entertained (again) in discovering the great (and distinguished) voice talent behind the animation.  I was actually able to correctly guess one person (the Rhino captain of the Prison guards), though everyone's voice will be vaguely familiar.
I highly recommend Kung Fu Panda for the whole family.

Short Attention Span Summary (SASS):

1. Noodle eating lazy panda, Po (Jack Black) dreams of becoming a kung-fu master.
2. He's really a waiter at the family noodle shop
3. A new Dragon Master is about to be named to battle the fearsome Tai Lung (Ian McShane), just in case he succeeds in breaking out of his escape-proof prison
4. The front runners for the job are the members of the "Furious Five" - Master Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Master Crane (David Cross), Master Mantis (Seth Rogen), Master Viper (Lucy Liu) and master Monkey (Jackie Chan)
5. Po drops in on the ceremony, causing an upset
6. The soup hits the fan when Tai Lung escapes
7. Master Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) has to make a martial arts master out of a panda bear, and fast!
8. With the right motivation, Po learns the secret of the sacred Dragon scroll
9. Crouching Leopard meets Lazy Panda with hidden Dragon
10. Exciting fight scenes ensue

Take the kids out for a treat
This kung fu cartoon's really neat
Despite his metabolic rate
This panda is a heavyweight

Well....actually......

We COULD ask for a sequel!

Amanda Richards, June 8, 2008

First, let me say, that a little Jack Black, for me, goes a long way.  When I heard that he was voicing Po, the main character of this movie, I wasn't sure if I could stomach the film, although the previews looked very good.  I'm glad to say that Black's performance is charming and sweet and this new animated offering from Dreamworks is a pleasant and welcomed addition to the summer box office.

  The story revolves around Po the Panda, who works for his father in a noodle shop but dreams of the exploits of his martial arts idols, the Furious Five.  These five consist of Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Monkey (Jackie Chan), Crane (David Cross), Mantis (Seth Rogen) and Viper (Lucy Liu).  Atop a mountain overlooking the village is the Jade Pallace, where these warriors train, led by their master, Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) and his master, a wise old turtle, Oogway.  By accident (or not by accident as the ancient turtle reminds them) Po is named the Dragon Warrior, much to the dismay of Shifu and his students.  However, once Tai Lung, a former student-turned villain, escapes from prison,  Shifu realizes he must learn to believe in the chubby, food-loving panda and train him for the fight ahead.  He knows that Tai Lung will stop at nothing to acquire the sacred Dragon scroll, believed to reveal great powers to the Dragon Warrior.

  Dreamworks delivers with this animated tale, full of rich, beautiful color and sharp, eye-popping animation.  The characters are entertainig and Po is endearing and loveable, a hero everyone will want to root for.  Thankfully, this is a film that both the kiddies and the adults can enjoy.  As with their Shrek franchise, Dreamworks' Panda offers humor that appeals to all.  I look forward to this little gem's dvd release.  Highly recommended!

Along with Shrek, Kung Fu Panda is Dreamworks best animated film to date by far. The voice talent is excellent, especially Jack Black and Dustin Hoffman. These two not only have the best characters in the movie, but they have the perfect voices to make them stand out from all the rest. Ian McShane is also really great as the villian, but Angelina Jolie, Seth Rogen and Jackie Chan are wasted. Seth Rogen has some good lines as Mantis, but Chan as Monkey gets only two lines of dialogue. What's the point of having someone as well known as him if he doesn't say more than a few words?

The animation itself is in the same league as Pixar (especially in the digital theater I saw it in). The colors and textures will make you feel your really in ancient China. The character models and details are as good as any that have come before if not better. You know they did a good job when you actually care about an animated creature.

Kung Fu Panda is funny throughout without sacrificing the story, which is better than you may think. It seemed like the kids and adults were laughing on the same wavelength most of the time, which just shows you how well thought out the writing is. It works for everyone.

4 and 1/2 out of 5 stars

This is the usual "loser makes good" plot as Po the pudgy Panda evolves from a lowly waiter in his father's noodle shop to the forecasted Dragon Warrior.  It is non-stop fun with enough quips and one liners to keep the attention of mom and dad.  I was there with my grand children and they loved it -- even the 17 year old thought it was worth seeing over "without all of the little kids".  I was especially impressed by the stunning art work and many scenes look like oriental paintings -- it is beautifully done.  I also was impressed by the fact that the movie just starts with little to no introduction.  This is clearly intended to immediately capture the interest of the small children  and I thought it did.  The credits are held until the end of the movie.

This is a very good movie and a lot of fun.  If you are looking for a film to take your kids to this is an excellent choice.  Mom and dad will like this movie just as much as the kids.

By day, Po the Panda (voiced by Jack Black) struggles as a waiter in his father's noodle shop.  But he dreams of being a kung fu warrior.

When he learns the Dragon Warrior is finally going to be named, he rushes to the temple and by accident ends up at the end of the Ooway the Ancient Turtle's (voice by Randall Duk Kim) pointing finger when he makes the proclamation. Master Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) and his five fighting pupils are all dismayed at the choice, but Ooway advises them there are no accidents.

Finally, when the snow leopard Tai Ling (Ian McShane) breaks out of jail and comes to wreak his vengeance on teh valley, Shifu agrees to help Po learn to fight.  All he needs is to believe in himself and work hard...

Dreamworks has done a great job with the CGI for this film. The animation is smooth and the characters really do seem real.  The Chinese countryside is beautiful as well.

Clearly, from the video games and plush toys you can find on Amazon, this movie may well be a contender for largest sales of related products.  The movie itself is entertaining for kids of all ages.

Rebecca Kyle, June 2008

I went to this movie for my 9 year old girl and didn't expect to do anything but sleep through it. I was very surprised that I really liked it and laughed with it. The plot is nothing we all haven't seen before but the  way it was done and the wonderful graphics made this a real gem. Give it a chance and you won't be disappointed.

DreamWorks Animation once again produces a computer animated film that contains topnotch animation, plenty of comedy, and recognizable celebrity voices. Kung Fu Panda also has a generous helping of heart, and Jack Black's voice performance manages to be exceedingly entertaining instead of generally annoying, as some of his live action routines tend to become. With martial arts action, adventure, and jokes for both children and adults, Kung Fu Panda is worthwhile family entertainment.

"There is no charge for awesomeness," states the all-powerful Panda warrior Po, as he dreams about fighting droves of enemies and defending his home, the Valley of Peace, with unmatchable martial arts skills and esprit de corps with his battling companions, the Furious Five. But when he awakes, Po (Jack Black) is nothing more than a clumsy and overweight panda noodle vendor who is destined to serve the valley the finest meals with his father (who is a goose). Po yearns to learn kung fu and help save his people by doing battle against all who threaten their way of life, but as his father continually reminds him, it is not his destiny.

Fortunate circumstances change everything one day when Po journeys into the city to watch the sage Master Oogway finally choose the legendary Dragon Warrior, prophesied to defeat the vile Tai Lung, a rogue warrior who has been locked away for years. The candidates are the legendary Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Monkey (Jackie Chan), Mantis (Seth Rogen, who seems to be in every animated film this year), Viper (Lucy Liu), and Crane (David Cross). When Po accidentally crashes into the arena via fireworks strapped to a wooden chair, Oogway pronounces the unconscious panda as the mighty Dragon Warrior. Shocked and thrilled, Po joins the five skeptical warriors in the Jade Palace as they train to battle Tai Lung, who recently escaped from an inescapable prison stronghold. But the greatest kung fu teacher Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) is outraged at Oogway's decision to leave the city in the hands of the unskilled panda. It will take everything in Po's power to live up to the designation bestowed upon him, and to prove that even a chubby lummox can master the martial arts.

Kung Fu Panda is another technically superior achievement for DreamWorks Animation, utilizing some of the best computer graphics and animators available. The movements, textures, fur/hair, backgrounds, and lighting are impressively realistic, even though the character designs themselves are largely cartoonish. But those designs are also outstanding, demonstrating a great sense of humor with Shifu's tiny mouse, Oogway's quivering turtle, Po's roly-poly panda, and even background characters such as a pig with five o'clock shadow. Going hand-in-hand with the hilarious character designs is the editing, which oftentimes mocks anime and martial arts films, and starts off in stylized 2-D animation during Po's dream sequence.

Gathering together a large ensemble cast of recognizable voices, for once the numerous celebrities don't detract from the film. Jack Black is nearly perfect as Po, who one might imagine as Black in a panda suit. Unlike this year's Horton Hears a Who remake in which Jim Carrey and Steve Carell's voices overshadowed their characters to the point of unrecognizable, Po is believable just as he is. Hoffman and the many supporting characters also deliver appropriately subtle performances that don't take the viewers attention away from the animated exploits onscreen.

Although the re-watching value might be slim for adults, and the underdog tale is understandably generic, Kung Fu Panda packs a punch with its traditional martial arts mix of fast-paced action, way-too-powerful villains, destinies, legends, prophecies, and killer kung fu moves. And to top it all off is constant comedy (albeit immature, "a kick to the tenders" comedy) that is sure to provoke chuckles from everyone.

- Mike Massie

This is one of my favorite animated movies.  It does a great job of drawing on all of those old school chop socky flicks where the student exceeds the teacher, only Po is no ordinary student.  His girth and appetite are a constant source of amusement and irritation but his redoubtable attitude and his zest for life are his real strengths.  All of the main characters are well drawn and enjoyable and Ian McShane voicing the villain is simply deliciousness as he sinks his pearly whites into the part.  The entire voice cast does a great job but Jack Black inhabits Po as few other voice actors have managed to inhabit their characters, and Dustin Hoffmans put-upon sensei is pitch perfect.  This is a universe Id like to live in for a day.  The Ultimate Edition of Awesomeness has a lot of fun features to it but nothing compares to the movie itself.

When I walked into the screening for Kung Fu Panda, my expectations were low. The movie's trailer looked only so-so and I was anticipating that the theater full of kids and I would be bombarded with heavy-handed Eastern mysticism, pummeled by imitable fist-to-face bash and smash, andbased on comedian Jack Black's past film choiceshanded a noodle bowl full of poo-poo humor.
I was pleasantly surprised. I found a colorful garden where I half expected a bog. Lush watercolor visuals and fun characters instead of flat animation and bland storytelling. A few kids will certainly come out of the theater itching to try out some of the roundhouse kicking, panda-belly-bouncing bedlam they've seen onscreen, but if the little roughhousing rascals a colleague of mine saw after the film are any indication, the moves they'll try are going to be of the friendly variety, not headlocks and punches. Previously stated spirituality is definitely present, but it's as spare as a martial arts cartoon set in ancient China will reasonably allow. And the humor runs clear and fresh.
In the film's production notes, co-director Mark Osborne had this to say: "It was important to all of us, from the start, that Kung Fu Panda would have a theme, a positive message that we really believed in. We wanted it to be a fun experience loaded with comedy and great action. But we also wanted there to be a takeaway that we all believed was a good one."
To that end, the story projects a well-worn "Follow your heart and believe in yourself" theme. But it also encourages finding your own strengths, being disciplined, learning from those who are older and wiser, protecting the innocent and standing up for what's right even when you're afraid you might fail.
Oh, yeah. There's one more thing this film encourages: hordes of cuddly stuffed animals forever frozen in kung fu pose.

This movie has a really cute message about the power to be great being inside all of us.  I was a little bit skeptical about how great it would be and was pleasantly surprised.  The panda, who was unhappy in his life, was pushed into pursuing his life long dream, amongst the ridicule of those who didn't believe he could do it.  He refused to give up, and with a little help, was able to conquer his enemy and save the village.

The artwork and details to Chinese culture are also pretty spectacular.  We watched it in my classroom as a little Chinese New Year treat.

Not very predictable and seemed extremely original for the most part. Really great movie. Action packed. Yet the scenes went by at a pace that was easy to follow and caused more "wow" then "what just happened" that i tend to get from a lot of action movies. Send a good if oft repeated message. The animation was top notch. The art direction of the scenery was well chosen and pleasing to the eye. The script was well thought out and original.

I don't like the actor that voiced the main character. Most the parts he has acted out in other movies just ground a nerve. He is just to good at acting out the parts he is cast in. He did really well in this movie though. The other voice actors did rather well too.

Kung Fu Panda is a really cute animated kids movie.  The gist - a lazy, out of shape panda who is raised by a duck family is mistaken for a ninja warrior.  He is thought to be 'the chosen one' who is destined to fight the bad guy who's been imprisioned for many years.  He's trained by his sensei and a group of other animal kung fu masters.

For kids, it's a really cute story with a fat panda who bumbles through things and blindly seems to come out on top.  There's a lot of 'fighting' (kung fu style) that keeps it fast paced and interesting.  There's the typical good guy vs bad guy plot.  There are plenty of jokes and it's overall a really entertaining film.

For parents, there are some jokes that are a bit above the kids' heads that will make you chuckle.  If you're into messages in your cartoons, there's a 'don't judge a book by its cover' and a 'you can do anything you can set your mind to' message.  There's also a message about trust, bravery and loyalty.

It's a cute movie worth watching.  I haven't seen the sequels, but I plan to check them out soon!

My kids and my wife and I LOVE this movie. As a voice actor, I'm always impressed with Jack Black in these KFP movies--he's so over-the-top in most of his other stuff, but he fits right into Po... almost like he's channeling himself for this role. Dustin Hoffman is HILARIOUSLY aloof when he's not enraged. The Furious Five were... well, they're really less than "furious" in a demonstrative sense (though Tigress does fairly seethe in every scene she's in... but it's still not Angelina Jolie's best work, I don't think). Really, they're not developed very much, but then again, the movie's not about them.

I would say, "If you don't like this, there's something wrong with you," but I'm not really qualified to make that kind of statement. But it's still probably true.

4 Stars. Dreamworks takes a page from Pixars book and creates an animation that was more complex than anything they did before. It also had a charming and captivating storyline and received a Best Animation nomination. It ultimately lost out to Pixars WALL-E (2008) but is definitely a close 2nd. Po (Jack Black), the only panda left, is fat and lazy. He has been raised by Mr. Ping, who runs a noodle shop and wants Po to someday take over. Po is also the biggest Kung Fu fan and idealizes the Furious Five; Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Crane (David Cross), Mantis (Seth Rogen), Viper (Lucy Liu), and Monkey (Jackie Chan). When Po tries to attend tournament where Kung Fu Master Oogway (Randall Duk Kim) will chose the Dragon Warrior, he is locked out. Po using a chair full of fireworks flies into the tournament and is named the Dragon Warrior, much to the Furious Five and their master, Shifus (Dustin Hoffman), disagreement. Shifus vengeful and dangerous pupil, snow leopard Tai Lung, soon escapes his prison and heads their way to get the Dragon Scroll. Its up the Furious Five and Shifu to overcome their differences with Po, and train him to defeat Tai Lung. Its up to Po to learn and turn his weight into an ability to become the Dragon Warrior.  Original meant to be a parody, the team behind Kung Fu Panda decided to make it an action comedy wuxia (martial hero) film that incorporates the heros journey narrative. With influences from a number of classic kung fu movies like Stephen Chows action comedy, Kung Fu Hustle (2004), Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (2000), Hero (2002), and House of Flying Daggers (2004). They also play homage to the Shaw Brothers with the characters, KG Shaw and JR Shaw. Tiger, Crane, Mantis, Viper, and Monkey are also all kung fu styles. Production designer Raymond Zibach and art director Tang Heng spent years researching Chinese painting, sculpture, architecture and kung fu films to help create the look of the film. Hans Zimmer even visited China to absorb the culture and get to know the China National Symphony Orchestra before co-creating the score with John Powell. With a stellar cast and all the preparation this charming movie is fun and has a lot of heart, which you expect from a great animation. Its a must see for kids and fans of the kung fu drama, as it stands up to some of the greats.

Po loves to play with action figures of the legendary Furious FiveTigress, Crane, Mantis, Viper and Monkey. He dreams of being in their ranks as a true deliverer of kung fu awesomeness. But, alas, he is only a chubby, stumble-footed and easily winded panda, not a lightning-fast, disciplined martial artist. So he's stuck in the family noodle business.

When word goes out that a Dragon Warrior will be chosen to fulfill legend and defend the Jade Kingdom from the dreaded martial arts master Tai Lung, Po can't contain his excitement. With a great deal of effort he lugs his considerable heft up the hundreds of steps to the Jade Palace to see who will land the great honor.

Turns out, he lands itafter accidentally crashing the tryout party.

Nobody can believe it. Especially not the Furious Five and their kung fu master Shifu. But since the enemy is already on his way, they have to do something. If Tai Lung gets his hands on the lauded Dragon Scroll, he will surely be powerful enough to rule the world. Po must do whatever it takes to face the fearsome and treacherous foe. Uh ... right after lunch, that is.
Advertisement
Positive Elements

Po wants to honor his father even though he is drawn to martial arts and not to the family business. When dad realizes where Po's gifts lie, he embraces his son and gives him his blessing. They both express their love for one another.

Doing your best and believing in yourself is a theme that runs throughout the movie. Master Shifu doesn't believe that Po is the right choice to defend the kingdom and initially he tries to get him to quit. But when the older and wiser Oogway asks him to train and believe in Po, Shifu submits to his mentor's request and gives the task his all. Later, Shifu risks his life to give the townspeople time to escape Tai Lung's wrath. And the Furious Five, though great warriors themselves, honor Shifu's request that they take care of the innocent rather than fight.

Master Shifu raised Tai Lung from a small cub and loved him like a son. Before the two battle, the elder master speaks of his pride for Tai Lung. But he goes on to apologize for how that same pride negatively impacted the angry fighter.
Spiritual Content

This being a martial arts story set in China, characters are influenced by the Eastern spirituality around them.

Oogway, the philosophizing turtle master ("Yesterday is history, tomorrow is a mystery, but today is a giftthat is why they call it the present"), has a dream that the imprisoned Tai Lung will escape his bonds and return to the kingdom (which comes true). He also believes that there are no accidents and that "the universe" has delivered Po to be their Dragon Warrior. When sensing that his end is near, Oogway dissolves into a swirl of fruit tree petals that float into the sky.

After being chosen as the Dragon Warrior, Po is ushered into the Sacred Hall of Warriors. There he finds an urn that is supposedly filled with the souls of a defeated army. And when he accidentally breaks the urn, a glowing puff of smoke is freed.

Po and Master Shifu visit a small mountain lake called the Pool of Sacred Tears that the master says is the birth place of kung fu. When seen from above, the pool looks like the ancient ying and yang symbol. In a dream, Po sets off to fight "10,000 demons of Demon Mountain."

[Spoiler Warning] A great deal of spiritual mystery revolves around the Dragon Scroll. Many believe that when a great warrior reads the scroll he will be imbued with magical superpowers. In truth, when the scroll is finally unrolled, it has nothing to do with magic at all.
Sexual Content

When Po clamps two noodle bowls to his chest, it gives the impression that he's wearing a bikini top.
Violent Content

Oogway is the only character who "dies." But the kung fu fighting is constant and furiousthough often presented in a humorous manner.

Beginning the starstruck Po's training, Shifu tells him, "The only souvenirs we collect here are bloody knuckles and broken bones." He proceeds to oversee Po's preliminary pummeling at the hands of the Furious Five as well as mechanical creations designed to poke, prod, whack, thwack, toss, tilt, twirl and burn would-be kung fu fighters.

There are a few battles with Tai Lung that, while not really scary, could seem fairly intense to very young viewers. He's a pretty powerful-looking, always snarling presence, much like Shere Khan from The Jungle Bookonly with roundhouse kicks. In one case, Tai Lung escapes from prison and battles numerous rhino captors with spectacular kicks, leaps and throws. The rhinos are hit (in slow motion) with their own spears and clubs. And the Furious Five battle the villain on a whiplashing rope bridge suspended above a bottomless chasm. (It looks like someone could fall to their death at any moment.) The bad guy paralyzes several of the Five with a nerve pinch. Tai Lung fights with Master Shifu and the two hit and kick each other with acrobatic swirls. Tai Lung throws blade weapons at his former master and Shifu knocks them aside. Shifu hits a stone pillar and is knocked unconscious.

[Spoiler Warning] The film culminates with a huge fight between Po and Tai Lung (which is played for laughs all the way through). Fur flies. A building collapses. Craters are blasted into the earth as bodies crash down upon it. A nuclear-level shockwave expands outward when the final blow lands. When it's over, Po runs to Shifu's side and it appears that the kung fu master has died. But he soon points out that he's really just getting some much-needed rest.
Crude or Profane Language

Shifu calls Po an "idiot." One of the Furious Five says that the panda has a "fat butt, flabby arms and a ridiculous belly." Later, when commenting on his performance, Po says, "I sucked more than ... anyone in the history of sucking."
Drug and Alcohol Content

None.
Other Negative Elements

A passing reference is made to gambling. Po straps himself and a bunch of fireworks rockets to a chair. When he lights them, he's blasted high into the sky.

When Po first shows up, the Furious Five are not happy about his presence. One says, "You're a disgrace to Jade Palace and everything we stand for."

Po is hit in the crotch while training and exclaims, "My tenders!" While being hit by Tai Lung, the panda's belly is jiggling so hard that he laughs, "I'm gonna pee."
Conclusion

When I walked into the screening for Kung Fu Panda, my expectations were low. The movie's trailer looked only so-so and I was anticipating that the theater full of kids and I would be bombarded with heavy-handed Eastern mysticism, pummeled by imitable fist-to-face bash and smash, andbased on comedian Jack Black's past film choiceshanded a noodle bowl full of poo-poo humor.

I was pleasantly surprised. I found a colorful garden where I half expected a bog. Lush watercolor visuals and fun characters instead of flat animation and bland storytelling. A few kids will certainly come out of the theater itching to try out some of the roundhouse kicking, panda-belly-bouncing bedlam they've seen onscreen, but if the little roughhousing rascals a colleague of mine saw after the film are any indication, the moves they'll try are going to be of the friendly variety, not headlocks and punches. Previously stated spirituality is definitely present, but it's as spare as a martial arts cartoon set in ancient China will reasonably allow. And the humor runs clear and fresh.

In the film's production notes, co-director Mark Osborne had this to say: "It was important to all of us, from the start, that Kung Fu Panda would have a theme, a positive message that we really believed in. We wanted it to be a fun experience loaded with comedy and great action. But we also wanted there to be a takeaway that we all believed was a good one."

To that end, the story projects a well-worn "Follow your heart and believe in yourself" theme. But it also encourages finding your own strengths, being disciplined, learning from those who are older and wiser, protecting the innocent and standing up for what's right even when you're afraid you might fail.

Oh, yeah. There's one more thing this film encourages: hordes of cuddly stuffed animals forever frozen in kung fu poses.

Kung Fu Panda is a truly immersive experience into the facinating world of oriental ursiday marital arts.  Jack Black wonderfully shows us how Pandas, while appearing rather endearing, actually possess a high aptitude for violence. The historical accuracy of this film is only rivaled by critically acclaimed feature films such as Mulan, Pocahontas, and The Little Mermaid. From a moral standpoint this movie was very black and white, which is refreshing in a world where gray areas seem to be ever widening. Great film. 5 stars.

I don't know what I could say that hasn't been eloquently said here already, but I do want to weigh in on this move. Perhaps it is special to me because it's the first movie I ever took my son (then 3) to see in the theater. But as the sequels have come out we've watched the original again and again alongside the new ones. Great stuff. I liked the animation, but the content is really where it's at for me. What a journey of self-discovery for (initially very goofy) Po, and as well for the 5. And master Shifu learned plenty lessons along the way too. We could all use a friend like Oogway. Absolutely chock full of the kinds of ideas I want my son to learn/internalize. I won't spoil it for those who haven't seen it yet by spilling Oogway's wonderful insights and sayings. It's hard for me to name a better movie for young kids and parents to watch together on a rainy day.

Kung Fu Panda is a great show that really is fun for the whole family. It tells the story of Po the Panda and takes us along with him on his adventures and misadventures. It teaches a lot of good lessons, has some good cartoon action, and a lot of comedy. Sure, there are a lot of cheesy parts, but I think that need more of that type of humor in our lives. I wouldn't watch it every single day, but I liked it enough that I bought it off of Amazon! I would recommend it to people who want a good cartoon and don't take either themselves or the show too seriously.

The main character was funny and Jack Black was a great pick for the part, but the movie was too steeped in eastern mysticism for me. It also portrayed kung-fu as merely a fighting art, when in fact true kung-fu was about an entire lifestyle that included poetry, music, math, and all of the arts and science. That is why so many of the animal styles developed, because of the kung-fu man observing nature  (science) around him. So kids just come away from this film thinking that life is about fist fighting! The very opposite of what true kung-fu taught.

This delightful animation carries a message to all of us who hope for a "dragon warrior" to save us.  It also offers encouragement for average people with personal challenges to deal with their problems through discovering root causes and confronting basic fears.  In the end we discover what true mastery entails and are invited to extend our thoughts beyond stereotypical ideas.  We leave the story inspired to follow our own dreams, not for personal gain but for the good of society.

Kung Fu Panda is good family fun!  As a kid growing up with Chris Farley and Beverly Hills Ninja, this is a much more kid friendly and enjoyable version.  DreamWorks Pictures has been doing a great job recently keeping up with Pixar and the other animated production studios.  In the vein of Shrek, they have an all-star cast of voice actors playing roles that you can envision them having a blast while making the film. There is a lot of fighting and cartoon violence, so I can understand if some parents are cautious to show their younger children. There is even some death and discussion of an afterlife in the film, but it is all in the context of Ancient China, so hopefully protective parents can justify and explain any differences reasonably. There are some silly things, like a panda being the child of a duck, that go unexplained in this film (but are addressed in the next :-D) that help keep the movie light and fun. Another thing to be aware of is the attention to the fact that the main character is overweight and the biases that he has to endure as such. There is a bit of glorification of the panda's overeating, but an educated parent should be able to point out that, in this case, the fact that he is a panda makes this eating habit a species-specific necessity, rather than an endorsement for kids to over-indulge. Overall, it's a great movie that has something for the whole family.

Ill be the first to admit that I was expecting something of a cutesy little kids movie when I learned that I could get a free digital HD copy, and that it is. But Kung Fu Panda exists on a deeper level for an audience beyond the age of nine about daring to become something greater than what your parents or society expects of you. The journey will be difficult without a doubt, but if you stick with it, you are going to be okay.

A deeply impactful and emotional movie for me who is in his twenties and is really beginning to wonder where his life is going. I think the best animated movies are those that contain a little something for everyone whether they are 4 or 80 because no one wants to go to or rent a movie for ninety minutes and be bored. Bottom line: Kids will love the Panda, Adults will love the message.

Now I get it why Kung Fu Panda raked in box office loot and warranted two sequels. This movie is like a box of frisky kittens or Betty White dabbing. It's damn adorable. I'm normally not a Jack Black guy since I most of the time find him obnoxious and excruciatingly mannered. But now I know I can stand him, provided he's doing only voice work and I don't have to eyeball him in the real. Black engagingly inhabits Po, a bumbling panda who toils ineptly in his father's noodle shop in some alternate ancient China. Let me mention that Po's adoptive father is a goose. A goose! The goose, Mr. Ping (James Hong), hopes that Po will someday take over the family business. Only, Po aspires to a loftier goal. He idolizes the Furious Five, that celebrated quintet of martial arts prodigiousness, each of which member embodies a particular discipline. He has action figures of them - how very anachronistic of him.

And, then, a momentous day, a game-changing day! Time has come to choose, from the masses, the mighty Dragon Warrior - him what's destined to open the dragon scroll and so obtain the secrets of the universe and fulfill an ancient prophecy. Well! Po, giddy fan boy, cannot miss out on such a pivotal martial arts spectacle. He attends on the pretense told his goose dad that he's gonna sell noodly goods.

There has to be dramatic conflict, and it comes two-fold. More immediate is the tense interplay between Po and his reluctant martial arts instructor, his sifu, him what can't believe fate had chosen  as the Dragon Warrior a fat, bungling, graceless, dumpling-scarfing panda. Lurking initially in the backdrop is the sub-plot of the malevolent snow leopard Tai Lung (Ian McShane), held in torturous confinement these past twenty years, but not for much longer. Some background on the big bad: Tai Lung, martial artist supreme, harbors a seething mad-on for his teacher. See, Tai Lung had considered himself the ideal candidate to be the Dragon Warrior. His teacher begged to differ. D'you ken how Tai Lung and Po's paths converge?

Kung Fu Panda showed out in 2008 and, eight years later, its life lessons still apply. A type of gentle humor abounds; it'll tickle the young uns' fancy and amuse the wrinklier persons. Po is the centerpiece, and he' so cute and affable, and an ungainly panda learning kung fu is simply a delightful conceit. Someone smartly reined in Black's excesses, and so what we get is voiceover work that integrates well with the visuals. Po consistently exhibits this disarming sense of wonder and of discovery, and this goes a long way into making him so rootable. But he's not the only attraction. It's a cavalcade of celebrity voices, with Angelina Jolie (Tigress), Jackie Chan (Monkey), Dustin Hoffman (Sifu), Lucy Liu (Viper), David Cross (Crane), and Seth Rogen (Mantis) adroitly filling up the spaces around Black.

Don't sleep on the action beats for they are dope, flawlessly rendered by wicked good CG animation. The martial arts sequences are handled with dynamic choreography and strewn with deft comic flourishes. At one point I was rendered giddy by a dizzyingly staged training skirmish between Po and his sifu waged with chopsticks and keying in on one lone surviving dumpling. I wager to brag that that scene qualifies as one of the most inspired sequences in martial arts cinema, let alone in cartoondom. And the life lessons I touched on earlier? I love it when movies don't serve up their messages in heavy-handed fashion. Kids will organically pick up on what this movie imparts: the importance of self-worth, that ain't no secret to greatness besides faith in oneself. Who needs a dumb dragon scroll?

I was really surprised by how good a movie this is. It's not just good-for-animation or good-for-a-kids'-movie, but solidly good-for-anyone-to-watch-anytime.
It follows most of the standard tropes of a martial arts movie, including the obligatory training montage, but one thing that struck me was the body-positive message subtly hidden there. Po becomes a bad-ass martial artist through training, but he doesn't suddenly become a ripped specimen of manhood in the process. He embraces his big belly and uses it to further his panda style kung fu instead of treating it as a hindrance.

Quite entertaining, but nothing seminal. I found it a bit awkward that among the Fab 5 were a viper and a mantis. I believe they could have found stronger candidates within the animal kingdom, but I guess they went with "diversity". There is almost no character development either, Jackie Chan (monkey) gets almost no lines in the entire movie (this could be his character thing, but except for Tigress, the other Fab 5 didn't get much screen time either). Also Po goes from nothing to Dragon Warrior way too fast. Of course realism isn't a priority in such a movie, so overall, I think it was a good way to spend 1.5 hours.

Any great parody must, at its root, stem from a love of that which is being parodied.

"Blazing Saddles" is both a brilliant parody of Western movies and their tropes, and a great (if deeply silly) Western. "Spaceballs" wouldn't be half so brilliant if it didn't work as a space opera.

"Kung Fu Panda" succeeds with flying colors - as a loving parody of kung fu cinema, it also stands as a great kung-fu film in its own right. Any lover of martial arts stories needs to give this one a watch.

My kids and I love watching this movie. It is super silly and funny - as to be expected with any Jack Black movie - and shows that even the strangest of people can be amazing. Po a panda bear that was raised by a duck and works at his father's noodle shop is told to take the noodle cart to the ceremony where a new trainee will be chosen. Po has dreamed and fantasized his whole life about being part of the Furious 5, an ancient grouping of warriors skilled in the art of KungFu, so the opportunity to see a new student chosen is almost as good as being able to BE the student. Unfortunately, Po is a Fat panda bear and struggles to get to the top of the stairs leading to the temple especially under the weight of his noodle cart. Little did he know that his desire to reach the top of those stairs would open up a whole new world to him.

We have been huge Kung Fu Panda fans from the day it was released. If you are looking for a fun family friendly movie I would totally recommend this great movie. Kung Fu Panda teaches kids the importance of determination, hard work, loyalty, and dedication. Aside from the valuable lessons, there's humor in it for everyone, including the adults. I guarantee you'll quickly fall in love with it. There's nonstop action, goofy mistakes, a valuable moral, and just all around good humor throughout the entire movie.

A pretty cute animated feature. I will say that this was a free film, and not something I personally would spend a lot to purchase. Still, if you can find it under the $10 barrier (maybe $5?), it wouldn't be a bad purchase. I really don't care too much for the current animation styles preponderant in today's world, but the work on this was decent enough. I liked the writing as well - though heavy on the humor aspects (but - this would probably be intended more for children/family viewing). The voice-work is also decent - fitting the characters nicely.

Bottom line: a very decent family-oriented film (maybe a little bit of cartoonish violence - but nothing I would think could distress anyone). I would think children (all ages) might enjoy it.

Kung Fu Panda is a great movie for kids.  It is funny, it is exciting, it has adventure, as well as great characters.  My kids love this movie and I'm glad that I got it for them.  If that wasn't enough, I think it is funny as well.  Jack Black is awesome and he makes the lovable panda come to life.  It is a fun story that inspires and captures your imagination.  I really enjoy watching it with me kids and honestly I am not sure who laughed more, me or my kids.

Kung Fu Panda is geared for kids, but it is an enjoyable watch for adults as well.  It is lighthearted and fun and honestly it was a great story as well.  It is well written with some fun lovable characters.  I hadn't ever seen it before and my kids had a long time ago and they remembered liking it so I bought it and I'm glad that I did.  I can't recommend Kung Fu Panda enough.  If you haven't seen it you need to.

Twentieth Century Fox decided to rerelease Kung Fu Panda and Kung Fu Panda 2 to coincide with the January 29 theatrical debut of the much-anticipated Kung Fu Panda 3. And when I say much anticipated Im not talking about anyone who lives in my house.

It took two weeks before I could even convince my two teens to finally watch the original Kung Fu Panda with me so I could review it for Family Home Theater. I have to admit, I don't blame them. The previews made it look like an all-action/no-cleverness Saturday morning formula cartoon. Maybe the studio was playing to the lowest common denominator, but if the trailer had included a couple of the many clever lines and character-driven moments instead of all that wax-on wax-off stuff, we would have watched it LONG ago.

Though critics whove seen the second sequel at early screenings have said #3 is the best of the bunch, the original film turns out to be a tough one to beat. In it, a Panda named Po (voiced by Jack Black) could be the alter ego for any number of slacker kids who aren't yet ready to face up to their potential, though that potential is all but proven by a dream for the future that they have. In Pos case, he wants to be a Kung Fu master, like Master Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Master Viper (Lucy Liu), Master Monkey (Jackie Chan), Master Mantis (Seth Rogen), and Master Crane (David Cross)though he was born into a family business, a noodle shopand I use air quotes because in Kung Fu Panda his dad (James Hong) is a goose. Is Po adopted? Is this cross-species family a writers joke? Could be, because it made us smile. And Po turns out to be the perfect hero for all the kids who have been told they are too short, too tall, too chubby, too uncoordinated, or too dumb to reach goals so lofty youd have to call them dreams.

Pos dad expects him to carry on the family businessa familiar tropebut destiny intervenes. When Po devises a fireworks way of launching himself into the courtyard of the temple so he can witness the coronation of the Dragon Warrior, a chosen one who can defeat the evil Tai Lung (Ian McShane), he launches himself right into the middle of the affair. And a tortoise grand master (Randall Duk kim) anoints him the chosen one. Hey, if he falls out of the sky, he must be right? Because there are no accidents.

Well, except for a visit to check on the security of the prison where the villain is kept immobilized, which goes horribly wrong. With an escape impending and doom just around the corner, Master Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) has no time at all to train Po to become the Kung Fu master he always aspired to, and the Dragon Warrior he reluctantly becomes. Star Wars fans will also recognize a familiar pupil-gone-to-the-dark-side storyline.

But the films familiar action-oriented plot doesnt come close to telling the whole story of this film, which is brought to life by sharp dialogue, terrific animation, and voice talents who can take that dialogue and use it to make their characters distinctive and sympatheticand none more so than Po.

This reissue comes with a bonus disc of special features. The main ones are three short Kung Fu Panda Secrets films: Secrets of the Furious Five (2008, 25 min.), Secrets of the Masters (2011, 23 min.), and Secrets of the Scroll (2013, 23 min.). These direct-to-video shorts capitalized on the popularity of the full-length features, and while theyll entertain young ones, the animation isn't up to the standards of the feature filmswhich are really quite impressive in their animation and set, character, and background designs. The other bonus features feel like filler: two mash-ups (blooper collections), a martial arts awesomeness music video, and a Kung Fu Panda 3 sneak peek, for those who haven't gotten to the theater yet.

Language: n/a
Sex: n/a
Violence: Some moments of fighting-related peril
Adult situations: n/a
Takeaway: Kung Fu Panda ought to have plenty of replay potential because its complex enough to satisfy with every new viewing.

I saw this movie on DVD, and I loved it! Beautifully written story about a Noodle-making Panda who dreams of joining the Kung fu Masters. It's a brilliantly funny film about believing in yourself, that even the most unlikely people can be heroes, and that it's about what's inside a person rather than training or strength. My favorite characters are Po and Tigress. As far as I am concerned, of the two Kung Fu Panda movies, this is my favorite.

Jack Black's comic genius along with groundbreaking special effects and a musical score that would make Mozart weep are just a few of the magical qualities that this masterpiece have to offer.  Thank you DreamWorks you have made my dreams come true, moment-by-moment, furry round house kick after furry Kung Fu chop.

Kung Fu Panda (2008)
Cast: JACK BLACK; DUSTIN HOFFMAN; ANGELINA JOLIE; LUCY LIU; JACKIE CHAN; DAVID CROSS;  SETH ROGEN; RANDALL DUK KIM AND IAN MCSHANE
DIRECTORS: MARK OSBORNE AND JOHN STEVENSON
GENRE: ANIMATION, ACTION, FAMILY ORIENTED
SYNOPOSIS:  Jack Black, stars as the voice of the lazy but overweight, Po the Panda who works in his father's noodle shop.  He dreams of joining the Furious Five, Tigress (Angelina Jolie); Viper (Lucy Liu); Monkey (Jackie Chan); Crane (David Cross) and Mantis (Seth Rogen). The Grand Master, Oogway (Randall Duk Kim) has a vision that the Snow Leopard, Tai Lung (Ian McShane) will escape from prison and head their way.  So Master Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) sends a messenger to the prison so they can double the guards to make sure Tai Lung doesn't escape but in the end he does escape.  Mean while in the Valley of Peace, Po is chosen as the Dragon Warrior  to the disappointment of Master Shifu and the Furious Five.  Po must believe that he is the Dragon Warrior, if he wants to defeat Tai Lung and save the Valley of Peace.

REVIEW:
Kung Fu Panda had me laughing all through the movie from the beginning to the end.  Jack Black is the perfect voice for Po the Panda.  The movie is hilarious and for me, the actors and actresses are perfectly cast.  Everything is done perfectly.  I love the movie with its characters, kung Fu sequences, beautiful story and background.  In the beginning, Po doubted that he was the Dragon Warrior but he had a talk with Grand Master, Oogway that made him change his mind.  Instead of quitting, he went back and trained in Kung Fu with the help of Master Shifu and soon believed that he was the Dragon Warrior.  Po's weakness for food soon becomes a strength to defeat Tai Lung.  This is a must see movie for children and adults.  It is comedy at its best.
In the end, the Furious Five went from wanting Po to leave to accepting him as the Dragon Warrior.

After I watched Kung Fu Panda, I believed that I was the master warrior. I was training myself all of the moves that Po did, and I was slowly becoming the master warrior. One day, when I was 7, a group of gangsters confronted me and stole my money. I decided it was my time to get them back. I came to the hospital where they robbed me before, and I went into my ninja pose. I started speaking Chinese to intimidate them saying, "CHING CHONG CHING," and they all looked confused. It was my confusion tactic. It was working. I aproached the men. Obviously, it was 15 years ago, so they looked older. I snatched the crane one of them was using to walk, and he fell to the floor. I screamed, "HI-YA!" and I beat him with the crane. I asked the other 80 year old man, "remember when you robbed me? " he then replied, "I've only ever token money from someone when they gave it to me for my charity. It's for cancer." I couldn't fall for that. I striked him with the good old classic move. The wippity wopity. He wasn't ready for it. I could tell he still remembered the power of the dark side- wait wrong movie. I could tell he still remember his strength, as I missed my hit. I knew there was only one way to defeat him. Dumplings. I threw 70 dumplings at him, and he looked even more confused. My confusion tactics were still working. I then ran at him, and tried to hit him with the good old, NUT CRUSHER, until a body guard came and tackled me. I woke up the next day in the same spot.

I wasn't entirely sure how I would feel about this movie, but since I had a free promo code, I figured I would get it! I am not typically a fan of Jack Black but I had heard good things about this movie. This movie was hilarious! As I said before, I had no expectations for it, so that most likely helped. It was a great comedy mixed with emotion and action, playing to all ages. Jack Black is the perfect actor to play Po. Po is a character that everyone can relate to as he laughs at himself, has misadventures, and dreams of what he wants. The character is actually developed very well, something that cannot be said about a lot of movies. I also really like the other two main characters played by Dustin Hoffman and Ian McShane as the other good and bad guys. I really like the landscaping and visual effects of this movie. The settings in China are so beautiful with the mountains and bodies of water.

Overall, this is a great movie that is beautiful to look at for all ages.

Excellent movie.  Fun for the whole family.  Voice actors do a great job and the animation is well-done and fun to watch.  I still remember taking my daughter to see this and all of the fun that we had as a family.  We still enjoy this movie and its sequel Kung Fu Panda 2 -- can't wait to see #3.

Recently re-watched this one again.  This is still a great movie.  If you have not seen this movie yet I highly recommend it.  Many times childrens movies are just full of adult innuendos.  This has some, but not a lot.  I do recommend for children and adults alike.  Even as a cartoon this is full of action as well as comedy.  I laughed a lot.  And even the action brought some intensity.  The story line went well and kept interest throughout.  Especially with the 3rd one coming out you should get if you don't have and do a quick review of number one and number two.  Another major pro that I have for this movie is the length.  It is right at ninety minutes, that is a great amount of time for both kids and adults.  I know 2 hours is only 30 minutes longer than 90, but it seems that a 90 minute movie is just right.
Jack Black and a full cast of acting royalty really flesh out this movie for both kids and adults as well.

All of these new cartoon HD movies are ridiculously entertaining or you are just too old to remember how cheesy old cartoons looked, but still had great humor though. These animated movies are techno wonders. I have been around long enough to remember Betty Boop, which was probably ground breaking back then. Stay young and watch one.

A cute movie that I enjoyed even as an adult. I look forward to seeing the sequels at some point. The only reason I took a point off was because of the rather simplistic and predictable plot. While I understand that it is first and foremost a children's movie, I can't help but recall some other animated kids movies that were much deeper (Lion King, Avatar: the Last Airbender). Overall though it is worthwhile to watch.

I cannot remember how but this movie was offered to me for free through my Amazon prime account.  My kids have always loved this movie and it is good to have.  This is a streaming version, so you must be connected to the internet to be able to view through your Amazon account.  I like to stream movies now now then own dvd, even more so with kid movies.  I can't tell you how many movies I have had to throw away due to scratches on the dvds.  This will never be the case with this film.

I have never had a problem with Amazon having buffering issues.  If you do it is probably the internet,s fault.  Some hotels offer free wifi but it is too slow to stream.  Check to see if they have an upgraded package for streaming, you will probably have to pay for it though.  But traveling with kids and not having entertainment isn't an issue if you have an internet device with internet anymore if you own streaming movies.  Gone are the days of forgotten movies at home and crying kids wanting something to do or watch when you are trying to get them to relax and unwind.

As for the movie if you have not seen Kung Fu Panda, it is a dream works film and it much follows dream works other works.  Great animation, good story line and fun family movie to watch together.

Kung Fu Panda is a 2008 American/British computer-animated action comedy martial arts film produced by DreamWorks Animation and distributed by Paramount Pictures. It was directed by John Stevenson and Mark Osborne and produced by Melissa Cobb, and stars the voices of Jack Black, Dustin Hoffman, Angelina Jolie, Ian McShane, Lucy Liu, Seth Rogen, David Cross, Randall Duk Kim, James Hong, Dan Fogler Michael Clarke Duncan, and Jackie Chan. Set in a version of ancient China populated by anthropomorphic talking animals, the plot revolves around a bumbling panda named Po who aspires to be a kung fu master. When an evil kung fu warrior is foretold to escape from prison, Po is unwittingly named the chosen one destined to bring peace to the land, much to the chagrin of the resident kung fu warriors.[1]

The idea for the film was conceived by Michael Lachance, a DreamWorks Animation executive. The film was originally intended to be a parody, but director Stevenson decided instead to shoot an action comedy wuxia film that incorporates the hero's journey narrative archetype for the lead character. The computer animation in the film was more complex than anything DreamWorks had done before. As with most DreamWorks animated films, Hans Zimmer (collaborating with John Powell this time) scored Kung Fu Panda. He visited China to absorb the culture and get to know the China National Symphony Orchestra as part of his preparation. A sequel, Kung Fu Panda 2, was released on May 26, 2011, along with a television series, Kung Fu Panda: Legends of Awesomeness later that same year as a part of a franchise. The third installment called Kung Fu Panda 3 will debut in January 2016.

Kung Fu Panda premiered in the United States on June 6, 2008, and has since received favorable reviews from critics and much of the movie-going public. The film garners an 87% "Certified Fresh" approval rating from review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes. Kung Fu Panda opened in 4,114 theaters, grossing $20.3 million on its opening day and $60.2 million on its opening weekend, resulting in the number one position at the box office. The film became DreamWorks' biggest opening for a non-sequel film, the highest grossing animated film of the year worldwide, and also had the fourth-largest opening weekend for a DreamWorks animated film at the American and Canadian box office, behind Shrek 2, Shrek the Third, and Shrek Forever After.

I got around to seeing "Kung Fu Panda" this year, when Amazon offered it as a special freebie for a limited time to Prime customers. Like many of the classic kung-fu movies to which "Panda" pays tribute, its comedy is mildly amusing and sometimes wince-inducing. The fight sequences are excellent. Then comes the final showdown between Po, the hero, and Tai Lung, the principal villain--this is where the movie really earns its stars from me. It's an inspired, rapid-fire parade of sight gags that hearkens back to the classic mid-20th Century animated shorts of Chuck Jones, Tex Avery and the Fleischer Brothers, and it brought out loud belly laughs from me watching those two careen around Peace Valley in a fight over a scroll whose message only one of the combatants understands.

Then, I had to convince my wife to watch it with me.  She's not into cartoons (I'm not much either) but the premise and such threw her off.  Finally she agreed to sit down and watch it with me.

Wow. What a fun movie!  I wanted to watch it again right after I watched it the first time, but needed to get some sleep.  If you have little children that are scared because of loud noises and things, then it might be best not to let them watch it.  Otherwise, it's a great & fun movie.  It was quite enjoyable.

I wish that I could say this of all of the other movies out there, in particular ones for children, but I can't.  You can tell that there was a lot of thought that went into the design of the movie, the script, and final cut.  I hope to see another movie like this someday.

I strive to write informative and accurate reviews, all thoughts expressed are my own.  My review may be subject to change via addendums and updates over time to track the long-term usability of a product.  The manufacturer or seller has not influenced my review in either direction.

Got this as a freebie promotion from amazon. The movie itself is ok if you have some time to kill, but nothing special. What I find annoying is you can only play the movie through the amazon player. I was expecting to get a full digital download that can be played with any video player software. I would be really ticked if I had actually paid for it. I would rather buy the physical blu-ray disk that I could then play on whatever platform I want.
The other annoying thing was I could not get HD resolution when playing it from my PC hooked up to the TV via HDMI cable. Why should that be? The hdmi hookup should be ensuring that DRM was all in order. To get HD, I ended up having to play it from the TV's amazon player app which is really clumsy to operate. Bottom line is amazon video sucks.

Offered the opportunity to receive this free from Amazon. Of course I turned it down. Drivel. READ A BOOK! Even a bad book can stimulate your imagination and creativity. Just think of the scathing review you could imagine yourself writing about the inept plot, the plodding characters, the stilted dialogue, the dreary prose used to describe the setting ... You get the idea.

If you are the social type, have a conversation with a friend or group of friends. INTERACT AND ACTUALLY LISTEN TO WHAT IS BEING SAID!! God forbid you might  learn something.

If you are a parent, read your children a book. SPUR THEIR IMAGINATIONS! As the story develops ask them questions like: what do you think will happen next; why do you think that character is doing that; if you wrote the story what would your ending be ... Help them become thinkers.

I used to see this movie being advertised and I thought I would hate it. I also couldn't stand Jack Black back then so he ruined it for me even more. However, when Kung Fu Panda 2 came out, my husband begged me to watch it in the theater with him and I agreed to do so. I wanted to watch this one first so I would know what was going on in the second one though. I am so glad I did! This movie is so funny! I love the panda and all of the other characters. This movie actually made me like Jack Black to a decent extent and I thought he played the part of Po (the panda) incredibly well. I think Kung Fu Panda 2 is funnier than this one, but this one is still great.

I have a daughter now who is three and this is one of her favorites. She loves pandas now because of this movie and she named her stuffed panda Po. She laughs so hard at some of the parts. We can't wait for Kung Fu Panda 3 to come out later this month. It will be the first movie she ever sees in the theater.

This movie is great for all ages. I really enjoy it as an adult and my daughter has enjoyed it ever since she first watched it when she was two. The humor is clean and I didn't notice any hidden sexual innuendo like I do in other kids' movies. Po is an out of shape panda who only seems to care about food and his favorite kung fu heroes. He ends up being able to work with his kung fu heroes even though he's so useless. That's where all of the humor comes in. There is violence in this movie because it's a kung fu movie, but it's mostly humorous violence and nothing scary or gory. It's great for the entire family, no matter what age and no matter what sex. I think it has some great lessons in it too.

There has since been a sequel and a third movie will be released this month 2015. I hope it's good and we see more from this franchise!

I've always been pleased with the ease at which Amazon could be used...until now.
The code is a never ending joke of frustration, if you use a Kindel Fire. And once you finally get it typed I t o the magic shrinking box, that automatically dumps you back at home page and erases your entry, if you mistakenly make the slightest error entering the ridiculous 16 digit promo code.
Also the brilliant software designer has the codex copy protected, so you can't cut and paste it.

Sorry Amazon, this is my pet peeve, and you get a solid thumbs down for this nonsense.

The only reason I give one star is because there isn't a raspberry emoticon offered to use.

You can bet I'll consider ordering more from the box stores in 2016.

Having just gotten a 4K UHD TV with passive 3D technology this Winter, I've been collecting and watching A LOT of 3D movies - especially animated ones. I own everything Disney and most of Pixar, but it wasn't until browsing the 3D section at Best Buy that I started collecting select films from Dreamworks. Having never seen this film before, I picked it up to watch with my sister and nephew on New Year's Eve since she said it was one of her all-time favorites. I was sceptical and figured it wouldn't be all that good - boy was I wrong.

This is EASILY one of the most beautifully animated films I have ever seen in my life - and the 3D is so expertly executed that it puts most other animated 3D films to shame. Dreamworks takes full advantage of the format in a flawless way that does not feel gimicky and rather adds to the emotion and excitement of each scene. Seeing this in 3D is nothing short of breath-taking from start to finish, my jaw hit the floor multiple times. There's so much comedy, action and genuine heart in this movie, and it's all balanced so perfectly with the pacing - it's the perfect example of a truly remarkable animated family film.

In conclusion, if you have a 3D TV, this is one of the best animated films you can get to really show off the format without subjecting yourself or others to mediocre story telling. I haven't watched part two yet, but I snagged that in 3D too and I'm itching to pop it in tonight. And if you find yourself wanting more quality 3D films from the studio, How to Train Your Dragon parts one and two are more great examples of amazing story telling and 3D animation done right. Disney really needs to step up their game; their presence in the Blu-ray 3D department is virtually non-existent, and both Dreamworks and Sony Pictures Animation are really dominating the format on home video with quality releases and a generous amount of re-pressings so that consumers aren't paying sky-high second-hand prices.

I'm sorry. Did I get an email saying that I got a promotional credit valid towards the purchase of a digital HD copy of Kung Fu Panda on Amazon Video? What exactly does purchasing a digital copy mean these days, because I thought it meant I get a digital copy that I can then watch wherever and whenever I want. THIS copy sits in the cloud somewhere and I can't download it to watch on my laptop. NOOOOOO. I need a "supported device" evidently for that. I guess my homemade quaint little htpc running Windows 7 isn't compatible enough?. Looky here Amazon - my video library is on my media server. If I can't put this movie on my media server so that it can stream to my devices then it isn't mine, and I don't own s*** except for the right to open a browser and navigate to some website to watch your movie. Why would anyone want to do that ? I don't keep my library on Amazon and how would I watch this on the plane anyways with no internet? No one wants to search 43 different locations where their movie might be. And I really don't want to open a browser to watch a movie anyways. So if I don't really get a copy then take your little promotion and shove it up your tailpipe. I have no use for your trickery. games, amd deception.

An orphan tries to befriend the popular kids at his new school.

The strength of this film is all on the performances.  And the voice cast does a surprisingly good job of performing their roles well.  And even though it does feel like a Jack Black vehicle, it downstream like it's just about Jack Black.

I'm grading this movie mostly on how my nephew enjoyed it.  By his own admission, it's not a favorite of his.  He saw it for the first time yesterday, and although he enjoyed most of it, he was bored during some stretches of the movie.  I think the movies very simpme story might actually be a knock against it for its intended audience.

Regardless though, it's a fun movie in spirit, that keeps it's energy up through most of the film.  And the characters are all very well realized, even if some of them don't get much to do.

Like I said, strongest point was in the voice acting.  Even though this was more names over actual voice talent, they all did pretty well with the roles that they were given.  I was full expecting an awful DreamWorks styled shove any minor celebrity we can in this film in spite of the fact that they aren't very good at voice acting extravaganza.  But this movie managed to reign that back quite a bit.

Overall, I'd recommend it for the kids.  It does enough to stay entertaining for younger audiences.  And it isn't so annoying as to become unwatchable for the older viewers too.

First to those having issues redeeming the free movie promo. You need 1) To be at a computer to purchase 2) Select "More Purchase Options" 3) Select enter Promo code, then enter it at the popup window and include "-" where they are in your code 4) it should show a green check mark, then click submit 5) go back and click to purchase HD $7.99 and confirm purchase. You can go into your orders, under the digital purchases and see they apply the $7.99 discount. If you get the green check mark but submit gives an error, close the popup window and make the purchase and it should apply the discount. If it does not click edit order and cancel. If you can't cancel call Amazon and they will issue a refund. The movie is free and if charged Amazon is great at understanding the issue, trust me i just bought the movie for $7.99 got a refund and walked through the correct purchase steps. Also once the movie is purchases you can watch it anywhere as my son is watching it on his iPad as i type. Now for the movie, its a kids movie and has its funny moments and kids seem to like it. I found it fine to watch and laughed at a few things. Take it at face value, its a talking Panda Cartoon made by Dreamwork's.

For those who got the freebie code for the download and are having trouble:

***Read the whole email offer again! It is confusing if you don't *READ ALL THE STEPS* before jumping to claim your goodie.***

But real quick, here they are again:

1. Click More Purchase Options
2. Click Redeem a Gift Card or Promotion Code
3. Enter your unique promotional code that is at the top of this email and click submit.
4. You will receive confirmation that your promotion code was successfully redeemed.  Exit out of the pop-up window.
5. Click the Buy Movie HD option.
6. You should receive an email confirming that a credit for the full value of the digital HD copy of Kung Fu Panda was applied to your order.

ONE NOTE: If you click submit more than once you will get an error code. It doesn't matter. Your account+offer are now already linked and completing steps 5 and 6 will lead to the redemption of your free copy of the digital version of "Kung Fu Panda".

Don't have an email offering you a free copy of "Kung Fu Panda"? There is a necessary purchase and more information on that is available here:
http://www.amazon.com/b?ie=UTF8&node=13529850011&ref_=pe_1534260_160177740

I don't usually make reviews like this, since it won't be useful for very long (the offer ends I think at 01/01/2016 some time?), but I know how frustrating technical things can be and this offer - While AWESOME! - could have been executed in a more user-friendly manner for sure!

Best of luck, hope this helps and happy holidays, folks!

The movie ITSELF is funny, filled with tender-hearted moments and growing pains.  Some light-hearted humor, spiced with moments of life wisdom.  Family and child-friendly, but enjoyable for adults too.  Great movie!  5-STAR  :)

The AMAZON PROMOTION ITSELF on December 19th, however, is NOT WORKING for multiple people, while some lucky ones seem to have no problems.  (I would rate THAT EXPERIENCE a 1-star!!!  It's unfortunate people are poorly rating the MOVIE instead of amazon, when it's not the movie's fault or reflection that amazon sent out bogus codes to numbers of people.)

I followed the step-by-step instructions (which were a little convoluted and not very user friendly I might add), but each and every time I attempted to apply the code I was given in the e-mail, I received the following message:

"The claim code you entered isn't working. Please ensure there are no spaces and try again. If this problem continues, please contact Amazon Customer Service at Video Help and refer to error 2039."

Yes, I double and triple checked there were no spaces - I even tried removing the hyphens just to see if it would make a difference.  It appears multiple people are getting error codes.

I sent an e-mail to Amazon about it, and am waiting to hear back...  It would be great if it would work - it's a fun movie for the family!

5. Click the Buy Movie HD option.
6. You should receive an email confirming that a credit for the full value of the digital HD copy of Kung Fu Panda was applied to your order.

The promo code was very easy to redeem! In your email just copy your promo code, click on the link, click more purchase options, click redeem a gift card or promotion code, paste your code, it will tell you it has been applied.(purchase price of $7.99 is still showing!)  Click purchase, then confirm. Your email confirmation & order history should say $0.00 after $7.99 promotion is subtracted.

The movie is clean, cute, great for all ages, and an oldie but a goodie.

As for the PROMO, I'm not easily confused, and yes it was easy per se. However, it -is- more tricky than the usual promo codes on Amazon and other sites. You have to enter the promo code, it says it's applied so clearly you think it's in your movie watch list already. Wrong. You then have to "purchase" it and you won't know you have the movie until Amazon sends you an email and you look at the total and see they indeed added the promo code and it worked. So yeah, it's more of a process in good faith. The directions are easy, but you don't know if it worked until you're staring at the email. (p.s. I cancelled my order bc I panicked and thought I'd bought it at full price. So I purchased it again with the already used code and it worked fine. I still got it for free.)

Hey! Guess what? If you actually follow the directions, it works! You get a promotional free download of the movie in seconds! Here's what they did wrong to make it confusing (Listen up, Amazon): You have to click 'buy the movie at $7.99." Nowhere does it say you got the movie for free, until you LOOK AT THE DIGITAL receipt!  Then you see that you get a CREDIT for $7.99, and you were charged 0. But if you don't look at the receipt, then you think you were charged for something you didn't want. So RELAX!  Watch the funny movie with your kids and lighten up, people!
