People, it's not rocket science. Just enter the promotional code using their directions. If you're not happy, just return the movie. No harm, no foul.

Edit: Here are the exact directions that they send in their email:
1. Click More Purchase Options
2. Click Redeem a Gift Card or Promotion Code
3. Enter your unique promotional code that is at the top of this email and click submit.
4. You will receive confirmation that your promotion code was successfully redeemed.  Exit out of the pop-up window.
5. Click the Buy Movie HD option.
6. You should receive an email confirming that a credit for the full value of the digital HD copy of Kung Fu Panda was applied to your order.

Please note onsite pricing will not change, however the order history will show a $0.00 charge for the title. Code is valid until 1/15/16 and is void if not redeemed by the expiration date. Terms and Conditions apply

I had the same experience as a number of other reviewers- I was offered the promo code for a free digital copy, but I admittedly didn't read the instructions carefully- I clicked 'purchase'- assuming that there would be an opportunity to enter the promo code before my card was charged, but there was no such thing. If I had clicked "other purchase options" the FIRST time, maybe it would have worked, but I cancelled my order, and THEN went back to click "other purchase options", and at that point, my promo code would not work. So I replied to the initial email to see about this, and I got a postmaster error message. So I went to "help". and, as always, my situation was not addressed in the any of the FAQ's, and finding out how to send a message to support is like finding a good Adam Sandler movie- not impossible, but not easy, either. I tried "chat" which claimed a 3 minute wait time, but I got a message suggesting that the wait time would be much longer, so please send an email. This promotion is not going to be very promotional for Amazon- I'm just annoyed by the whole affair, and I don't even care about this movie............it's just .... free... (not)/ UPDATE- Really frustrating experience with AZ customer "service" (which I'd previously considered to be quite good).

Alas, like SO many others, I failed to PROPERLY FOLLOW DIRECTIONS the first time I tried this. I cancelled my order (instructions for which are found in multiple locations on Amazon's website), reread the directions, and FOLLOWED them the second time without a problem. Everybody who posted a derogatory, inflammatory, or otherwise negative review needs to just CHILL. Take a deep breath, and try again. IF you do it the way you are instructed, it will work. For the rest of you who didn't have a problem, I salute you. Your reading comprehension and ability to follow written instructions are commendable! We need more people like you in the world today.

For the longest time, I saw ads for "Kung Fu Panda" and thought, "Oh my gosh--that's going to be an awful movie."  Generally speaking, martial arts movies for kids don't work out well ("3 Ninjas," "Sidekicks," "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 2," anyone?), so figured this would be more of the same.  Having been on a bit of a martial arts kick (pun intended) lately, I saw that "Kung Fu Panda" had actually gotten pretty decent reviews, so I figured I'd give it a shot.

Definitely not the best animated movie ("Spirited Away") or the best martial arts movie ("The Karate Kid," "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon") I've seen, but it's certainly fun, and Jack Black's Po is a likeable character.  I really like that Po's father is a duck, and that all the movie's characters are animals of one sort or another.  It's a nice nod to the "animal" styles of Kung Fu, which really do exist.  The movie's central lesson--"The secret is that there is no secret"--is spot-on as well.  It's good for children to realize that there's no shortcut to getting what they want, but that hard work, belief in one's self, and using one's strengths (even if they are humor, cooking, and the ability to jump ten feet in the air for cookies) are how to find happiness in life.

Definitely worth your time.

It amazes me how Disney has to go out of their way to promote a movie like "Frozen" and spend millions on marketing to push it to the top 10 movies of all time which I couldn't bear to watch a second time though it wasn't bad! And here DreamWorks has on its hands a masterpiece in "Kung Fu Panda" that beats all the other releases from either house. With amazing animation sequences, background score, magnificent backdrops that highlight Chinese art and culture plus, superb and hip dialogues with the voice characterizations portrayed by Jack Black (Po) and James Hong (as Po's father), powerful proverbial notes from Dustin Hoffman (Master Shifu) and Randall Kim (as Master Oogway) besides a heart-felt storyline; the movie has great repeat viewing quality and shines in it's own right as one of the best animation movies of all time!

I had only ever watched the very beginning of this movie, but had always heard good things about it. I decided to hold my breath and find out for myself and I'm so glad that I did!! This movie is so clever, filled with fantastic kung fu fighting animals of all kinds who are memorable for both their wit and their heart. I laughed out loud throughout the entire film! This movie is great entertainment for kids, teaching them that anything is possible if you just believe in yourself, and it's great fun for the adults as well!! Great for the entire family. We absolutely adore it!

I would like to say that personally I prefer animated movies.  I really liked this movie as it takes the average character and thrusts them into a role or situation that requires greatness.  It presents the story that dreams can come true and that everyone can learn something from someone else, no matter how ordinary the person or how extraordinary the person may be that you're learning from.  It also presents the theme of teamwork and support.  I like the humor that this movie injects with Jack Black as Po.  It has the emotional ups and downs that any good animated film requires to capture people of all age ranges.  The scenery and graphics are also very well put together and it's easy to be fully captivated by the story.  Overall a great movie for all ages.
I purchased this movie for my son and the entire family loved it.  This is definitely a classic and the message is very important.

BD video is top notch, and it's movies like these that make the BD format really worth it.  The only reason I don't give this a five is knowing a 5 is the perfect BD and awesome as this is, I don't think its perfect yet.

The witty humour, the hidden adult humour, the fight sequences, the visuals, and the storytelling, are all small parts that come together to make this movie one to remember. Dreamworks has definitely hit it's mark in super-stardom. Common sense has just been kicked into me and I am ready for so much more. This movie is just not enough. Kung Fu Panda is incredible!!!

This is like if I went to walmart and I bought a dvd and they showed up to my house and said they lost the licensing to sell it they have to take it back. this is very disappointing and when speaking to the reps which is not there fault they basically say this is amazons policy this is how it works buying digital movies even thought you buy and own them you can no longer watch the movies because they lost rights. i've never watched this movie despite having seen it airing on cable (changed the channel). i thought since it is dreamworks and 3d, i will probably enjoy it. instead, there were only a few funny moments for me. i didn't find any part of the plot particularly touching besides the brief story between shifu and the cub. dreamworks movies always have a heartfelt spark to them, and this movie was seriously lacking. the 3d didn't wow me except in two scenes (fireworks rocket and flying petals). so ultimately, i feel disappointed in this blind buy and regret spending so much money on this 3d blu.

there are too many cliches about chinese culture in this movie and it is hard to like this panda. none of the characters were memorable or well developed besides shifu. maybe because i do not like jack black much, i did not care for this movie. if you are amused by stereotypical comedies like american pie, dumb and dumber, meet the fockers, or whatever....this might be for you. children will most likely enjoy it though.

Weird licensing issues: we wanted to buy rather than rent, but we were informed that the license rights change later this summer. Essentially it said that either download to a compatible device by X date or lose access. It wasn't clear if this meant that the movie was tied to the specific device at that point--do you lose it altogether if the device breaks or you have to reinstall your OS? Such issues make me less confident in other Amazon video purchases in the future.

FWIW, the video quality was great, and actual movie (independent of the format) was fantastic.

I'm really, really not an animated movie fan, but I was looking for a present for my 3 granddaughters who live far away, so purchased a few that seemed to have good reviews. WOW! If Kung Fu Panda (1 & 2) are examples, I may need to buy a lot more!

Kung Fu Panda (1) was funny, acerbic, witty, sad, and completely enthralling! Watching a roly-poly panda begin to learn kung-fu is side-splitting, especially for those of us who are a bit roly-poly ourselves! :)

The voices for the various characters could not be more spot on. Jack Black has raised the bar for animation voices so high I'm not sure it will ever be beat!!! (I will add an aside here for Andy Serkis' performance as Gollum/Smeagol in LOTR however, although, technically, I don't consider that "animation" such as this. Gollum was on another level entirely!)

One slight note of caution; 1 of my granddaughters is 2 1/2, and I think this may be just a little too much fighting for her. It should be fine for 4 or 4 1/2 +, though.

I loved the original 2D version as DVD - enough to happily buy the 2D Blu-ray and I was delighted to find state of the art application of both high definition video and audio in that format. However when I found out that a 3D version of this original Kung Fu Panda movie had been released, I initially hesitated to purchase it - mostly because of a lack of reviews for that version - but now that I have seen the 3D Blu-ray I cannot understand why there are not dozens of rave reviews for it. My brother and I have over thirty 3D Blu-rays, and I reckon that the quality of 3D design here is certainly as good as in Up! (which is my standard for excellence in that format). Kung Fu Panda is a wonderful story which is ideal for all ages - being heart warming, inspiring, engaging and highly entertaining. It has a magnificent sound design (especially in surround) and every frame of every scene is pure art - made all the more appreciable in 3D. Naturally I highly recommend the Kung Fu Panda Blu-ray 3D.
I like the cast in this one. And it sends a pretty great message. You don't need super powers or special secrets to be the best... just be yourself. I hope kids take that message from this movie.
What's not to love- Jack Black, roly poly panda, cute dumplings, inner peace, fabulous graphics and cartoon creativity.  One of the best cartoons around.

This disc was described in my player as disc 1 of 3, of the 3D Blu-Ray edition.  NOT the same as the packaging.  It does not play in any version of media player on my computer, as it is "protected content."  Disappointing and sent back immediately.

Kung Fu Panda is a gem in that it is inspirational, uplifting, deep, and hysterically funny. It also helps that the stars voicing the characters are all amazing actors whose talents add the perfect touch to this well-crafted film.

The film follows "Po," a bumbling Panda Bear voiced by Jack Black who seeks a different Path than that of his master chef father. Through chance/fate ("there are no accidents"---quote), Po becomes a novice disciple of a stern, inner-peace-seeking shifu who cannot quite fathom how to turn Po into one of his prodigies. The following "training" sessions designed to toughen Po (or send him bouncing down the stairs back to his old life) are a combination of slap-stick humor and well-written puns and come-backs.

The other martial artists are Tigress, Crane, Monkey, Mantis, and Python. Each is well-versed in their art, each has a different specialization (the speed of python, the power of Tigress). They tolerate Po but feel that his presence is a mistake. Yet, the decision of the elderly Tortoise sage to stand by Po and the legend of the Dragon Scroll makes them both curious about Po and defiant at the same time.

There are several scenes that remind of the Tao Te Ching, as translated by Gia-Fu Feng and Jane English. The issue of excessive pride reminds me of verse 3, line 1: "not exalting the gifted prevents quarreling." The issue of nothingness reminds me of verse 11, lines 3 and 4: "shape clay into a vessel; it is the space within that makes it useful." The issue of Po's humiliation reminds of verse 13, line 1: "accept disgrace willingly." If one listens to the script of Kung Fu Panda, the lessons are imbedded in the story. Beautiful, deep, articulate.

Lastly, the story is uplifting, through humor, story development, and heart. Wisdom is imbedded like so many seeds of Peach trees throughout the soil of the story (film reference to the scene of the Tortoise sage and the shifu).

Just a side note, I prefer action movies, dramas, and thrillers. I watch these kid's movies only because my mother loves them. I went into this film fidgeting and sighing about how I had to sit through it, but afterwards, I was grateful and in a good mood.

I highly recommend Kung Fu Panda if you have kids or if you do not have kids. It works for everyone. I am smiling right now just remembering the scene where Po finds Monkey's stash of cookies on the top shelf. It will make sense once you see the movie!

There are many things about this film that I appreciate, such as the fact that all characters in the movie are endemic Chinese species, that the music is delightfully correlated to the film's visuals, and that watching Po's struggle, and more importantly, the struggle of a weathered but wise Master Shifu, was on a psychological level very interesting. I felt that the pace of their turnarounds were realistic, and it all came together in the end. Po may be fat, but it makes sense that a thick-skinned panda would be required to defeat Tai Lung because apparently the layers of adipose protect him from the villain's famed nerve attacks.

All around this is a great flick, not for its humor alone, but also its visuals, poignant music, and heartwarming story.

There are some adoption issues in Kung Fu Panda that get more fully addressed in the sequel. In this movie, what we see is that Po is a panda bear. His father is a goose. Po's father points to portraits of various ancestors, and they are all geese. While Po's adoption is not directly addressed, it is hinted at lightheartedly; Po expresses that sometimes he "can't believe" that he is the son of his father. Mr. Ping hints at telling Po something that Po should have known for a long time, but ultimately shares a secret family recipe rather. In the next movie, Po and Mr. Ping discuss adoption; for now, we're just left with an uncomfortable "non-dealing" with the issue. The villain of the movie also was adopted, at least to some extent: Tai Lung was found and raised by Shifu. Although adoption is not mentioned by name, Shifu took Tai Lung in, and raised him like a son. Shifu believed that Tai Lung would be appointed Dragon Warrior, but Shifu's master Oogway saw darkness in Tai Lung (we're never told the reasons). Tai Lung became bitter, turned on Shifu, and was imprisoned. He returns to his former home for revenge. A main thrust of the movie seems to be Po's identity development. He doesn't like who he is. He wants to be someone else. Some of his questions are probably rooted in his adoption. In this movie, the question: "Can I be someone else?" is answered with "Who you are is fine." In the next movie, Kung Fu Panda 2, the question is "who am I, really?"

I love this movie! This is my all time favorite computer animated film! I love pandas, I like tigers, I like vipers, I like Chinese stuff, this movie is so awesome! Plus, I thought it was WAY better than Dreamworks' last movie"Bee Movie." I gained an interest in China and pandas a year or two before this movie came out and a lot of it entertained me! Hans ZImmer and Powell's score for this was great, the drama was great, and even the comedy was great too! I will admit, I didn't quite enjoy the way the Five treated Po when he first got to the palace, particularly Tigress, but I like how they changed their minds about him over time. I expected Shifu to hate Po as well and he did know he had to change his ways toward Po when Oogway died. Tai Lung is a pretty cool villain too. He actually reminds me a lot of Shere Khan from "Jungle Book". I don't know what else to say about this movie. I just love it so much!

I'm just this guy, y'know? I yam what I yam, and no one to date thought very much of it. Maybe the opposite, if you focus on a wedgied eighth grade. But I'd give anything to be this way-awesome master of way-awesome beatdown skills (on all those guys who beat me down, at least), as long as it isn't too hard. Heck, I'd take a fair beating too - not like I haven't done it before - as long as the cool guys let me hang with them.

If you're still with me, then KFP is your ultimate fantasy. The golden goal is to find that unique power that each of us has within. Yeah, and everybody wins the race and gets a hug at the end. But maybe, just maybe, that one thing about you really can stand tall in some squirrely place in the world. Then, you are Po. Po Panda.

Perhaps there's a reference here to Li Po, the classic drunken poet - perhaps not. I really don't care. It's just a fun flick with lots of satire on the traditional "work hard forever" themes that don't work so well in the current decade. Po is the guy you really want to like, even if he's ... well, y'know, not so hard-working.

The animation matches the best of today's, and voice casting backs up the animated characters as well as any. My one kvetch, and little, is that Angelina Jolie's voice was way too smooth for Master Tigress. My ears just kept looking for a rocky rasp that her honeyed soprano never delivered. My problem, not yours, not hers.

As long as you don't take the martial arts too seriously, this is a charming and humorous riff on taking them seriously. See it and laugh at it. If you can be polite about all the rest, it's warm fuzzy fun.

-- wiredweird

There is always a great twist.  Not so here which is why I can't give it 5 stars but my expectations for anything kung fu (even animated) are pretty high.

My friends and I, one day, decided to have a movie marathon day.  On that day, Kung-Fu Panda was selected for viewing.  I'll admit, I was skeptical at first; for one, it was a kiddie movie, and two, it starred Jack Black (his acting style does not agree with me nor does his comedy).  However, after watching the movie in its entirety, I was surprised with how good it was.  It managed to have that kid-able-to-watch quality to it without being cheesy or dumbed-down.  It is now one of my favorite movies, and it looks stellar in HD.  I highly recommend this film to those who like animation (particularly CG animation), martial arts, action, and comedy movies.

Kung Fu Panda was a cute story with some interesting messages told in a back-drop of martial arts mania. The panda is Po, a lazy bear whose father (a duck! -- they never explain that, which is humorous in itself) runs a noodle shop. Their family has had many generations of noodle shops and he looks forward to the day when Po can take over the family business. But Po has other dreams. He is the martial arts warrior looked up to by all. He is the kung fu master who beats all enemies. But then he wakes up, admires his action figures and goes back to work selling soup. I really liked how the story unfolded, with Po meeting his stars of the kung fu world, working with them and being elated to even see them. But Tigress, Viper, Crane, Mantis and Monkey are less than thrilled when Po is named the Dragon Warrior. Themes: Pop philosophy make its way into this film as other animated features of this type. There is the past which is history, tomorrow hasn't happened yet, so all you have is the NOW. And the NOW is a gift, that's why it's called "present." Cooool! All fun aside, I did have to admire Po and his not wanting to give up -- he did at first -- and how the master also changed, realizing that Po, being a different kind of fighter needed a different kind of training. The mixing of kung fu and dumplings was hilarious. Bottom Line: Great story, detailed animation and wonderful voice actors come together to make this a fun movie to watch and learn from. Martial arts purists might whine and complain, missing the point of this light bit of entertainment. Can't wait for the sequel! *** This review may contain spoilers ***

When Kung Fu Panda was released in China, it was praised not only for the production values but its faithfulness to Chinese culture. Suddenly people in China were asking, how can an American production company outdo their Chinese counterparts in creating an animated film that sends such a positive message about China and gets everything right? It's akin to the Russians who launched the first man into space, only to see the American overtake them, eventually landing a man on the moon. For many Chinese critics, Kung Fu Panda is the American 'first lunar landing' of animated martial arts movies.

But if the Chinese critics only had a bit of critical acumen, they could easily see there's nothing to be jealous about here. Sure there's a great amount of respect for Chinese culture seen throughout the film (down to the last Chinese character in the credits) as well as some sensational animation including the opening anime 'dream' sequence as well as that incredibly difficult feat of having tons of realistic looking confetti pour down at the Kung Fu tournament where the Kung Fu Panda, Po, is crowned Dragon Warrior. But how is Chinese culture honored by turning Chinese people into a bunch of goofy, self-effacing anthropomorphic animals? Surely kids under eight will dig it, but adults? I hardly think so.

While the directors of 'Panda' are firmly ensconced in the world of martial arts and action adventure films, they are neophytes when it comes to comedy. It all comes down to one silly slapstick scene after another emphasizing Po as a good natured, bumbling fool with a decided inferiority complex. Whether he fails getting up the steps into the arena for the Kung Fu tournament, or shoots himself high into the air strapped to a bunch of fireworks and then unceremoniously falling straight down and landing inside the arena, only to be crowned Dragon Warrior, the idea that we should fall in love with his lovable loser is spelled out from the beginning and repeated ad infinitum. How many times do we have to see Po chucked around like an inflatable doll whether it's by Master Shifu, Villain Tai Lung or when he finds himself caught inside the mechanical torture chamber, a device that Shifu's Dragon Warrior candidates, 'The Furious Five', in contrast, have mastered.

I do confess that Master Shifu's 'epiphany' in realizing that he has to train Po in a different way so that he can succeed as the dragon warrior, might have been the most clever moment in the comic arc of the film. And certainly Po's transformation from self-effacing masochist to gleeful aggressor as he embraces his 'appetite', is a welcome plot twist after being subjected to the one joke idea of Po as a bumbling clown. Yes, there's finally a method to Po's madness, as Tai Lung is unable to harness Po's new found manic energy. It's sort of like a dominant major league batter unable to master the completely unpredictable path of a knuckle ball.

But if we view Po as representing a grownup who still acts like a kid with the particularly bad habit of overeating, then the message 'be yourself', should fall on deaf ears. In this day where smart educators are trying to control the epidemic of childhood obesity, Po's unbridled enthusiasm for that extra cupcake, would not lead to his triumph as dragon warrior. It's a wishful conceit on the part of the directors that Po would end up victorious in his confrontation with the evil Tai Lung. The filmmakers' message to kids here is be happy even if you don't treat yourself well. And things will turn out alright even if you've made no effort to change yourself.

As for the action adventure aspect of 'Panda', I can't help it if it seems that the 'holy trinity' of Shifu, Oogway and Tai Lung, are pilfered straight out of the Star Wars play book. Shifu appears to be a Yoda stand-in with the wise, all-knowing tortoise Oogway, reprising the Obi-Wan Kenobi role (Oogway appears to employ his own version of 'The Force' as he is responsible for turning the slight Red Panda Master Shifu into a powerhouse). Finally, Tai Lung can go toe to toe with Darth Vadar any day as both have no problems mixing erudition with brute force.

A good deal of 'Panda' is taken up by one Kung Fu sequence after another and you really have to be a martial arts fan to be enamored with all those repetitious action sequences. Less bothersome (but still silly) was the decision to make Po's father, Mr. Ping, a goose. There's also the Wuxi Finger Hold that leads to Tai Lung's destruction (at first it seems like a nuclear explosion but it really is a clearing out of 'bad energy' or 'bad karma'). Finally, The 'Furious Five' are not distinct enough as characters despite the conscription of such luminaries as Angelina Jolie and Jackie Chan to perform the voice overs.

I think 'Kung Fu Panda' would have been a better film had the films' scenarists decided from the outset not to make Po into such a hapless buffoon. That would have also probably meant that the sentimental Mr. Ping and his love for noodles had to go too. In its present incarnation, Kung Fu Panda is certainly suitable for kids (although Tai Lung's antics might be too strong a draught for children under eight). As for adults, ignore the dopey screenplay and concentrate on the visuals and the music, which certainly deserve the accolades already garnered throughout the film community since the film's release in 2008.

Honestly, I am in my early twenties and think that this movie is one of the best movies ever made by Dreamworks. This movie has no crude or vulgar elements to it which for some reason many people my age have always thought to be funny. It is genuinely funny from beginning to end, has a great story, and is very beautifully done. There is always a message in it and Jack Black's character is not just another mindless, obnoxious character that are so many adored today. His character is very funny and has a great attitude throughout.
So again a movie that has no vulgarity and is genuinely funny with a lesson at the end...When else can you get that in a kid's movie nowadays? GREAT movie. Definite 5 stars

This Mandarin Chinese version of Kung Fu Panda has high-quality sound and the option for subtitles in Chinese. It's great fun for kids who are learning Chinese. IMPORTANT NOTE: you must have a universal DVD player. A regular US DVD player will not play this DVD.

I bought this DVD for my nephew and he loves it! In fact, he has about worn the DVD out! This item was just as described and I would recommend this seller. Fast shipping and I will buy from this seller again. : )

The one scene where Po and his Master fight over the dumpling -- by itself, this makes the movie worth the price of admission. I'm not a Jack Black fan, but I gotta admire his spot-on impression of a fanboy. ("Whoahhh!") His voice work is all the more amazing when you leave the room and listen to it from the kitchen, and you hear the sheer variety of grunts, screams, and sighs he had to come up with -- all without any idea of how the sparring scenes would look. In animated film production, the voices are recorded first, and the animators "draw" to match them. This means that Jack (and all the actors) had to work from pure imagination. One wonders how many takes he had to do, until the sound engineers got enough different exclamations from him that they could place them wherever needed. My daughter LOVES this movie. A brilliant send-up of the Chinese martial-arts genre, without in any way being condescending.

Picture quality on this movie in blu ray is second to none, sound is very good also.  Good movie and has a high replay value, my little boy loves it and I don't mind watching it with him because I love kung fu.  There's a saying: "Yesterday is history, tomorrow is a mystery, but today is a gift. That is why it is called the present.
Original blu-ray plus a DVD copy. A good deal! Movie itself is excellent on Audio and video quality. Can't wait to preorder Kung fu Panda 2 Blu-ray.

Jack Black stars as Po, a goofy, lovable loser panda who suddenly has destiny call to him to be the "dragon warrior," much to the chagrin of the much more skilled warriors. Black does a solid job of giving personality to Po, making his status as underdog come to life, as he stumbles, and bumbles his way alternately through skills tests and stuffing his face. The master often laments, "There are no accidents", but when you see Po's "skills", you begin to wonder if the master could be wrong.

Kung Fu Panda is a great family film. It does have a few minor parts of crude humor, but where it excels is in its entertainment value, personality, and ultimate message about belief in fulfilling your goals or dreams. So often you watch animated films that force the sentimental moments and they come off as a little too forced or cheesy, but Kung Fu seems very genuine in the way it presents life's lessons in not giving up.

I normally have great experiences with Amazon, but this DVD came bent. I tried playing it in my XBox360, DVD player, and laptop. It didn't play at all in my XBox and laptop and skipped in the DVD player.

'Kung Fun Panda' is your basic fun, family computer animated movie. It has lots of silly jokes, cute characters and a simple, yet humorous storyline. It follows Po the panda as he gets trained to be the dragon warrior and how he is treated by the other kung fun pupils. There is a high 'star' voice-over list for this film, including Jack Black, Dustin Hoffman, Angelina Jolie and Jackie Chan and they all do a great job bringing life to their various characters. It seems strange to ask Jackie Chan to do a voice over as he is a very physical actor and was barely used in this film, but it lends the film some martial arts kudos I guess. This is a good film for kids and is fun enough to keep parents interested as well. At just under 90 minutes it's not too long so kids will lose their attention or parents will get bored. It does what it sets out to do well, be a fun animated adventure, but there are better animated films out there and this has a great deal to live up to (hence the 3 stars). Worth a look, but not one to rush out to buy the first time you hear of it.

I love this movie. It's not perfect, but it's darn good. It's sort of an animated Karate Kid, set in ancient China (or some version of it) and starring animals...and the main character is a fat panda. Ok, so Karate Kid might be a stretch on the face of it. But it's that type of story.

* spoilers *

Po is a fat panda who dreams of being a great Kung Fu fighter. Instead, he's a food-aholic who has a hard time getting out of bed in the morning. To top it off, he doesn't have the razor sharp claws and teeth that Tigress has, or the wings of Crane, or any of the other top fighters' abilities. Fate intervenes, however, when he is chosen as the Dragon Warrior who must protect the Valley of Peace from an escaped evil doer/super fighter. And, of course, he does it.

* end spoilers *

The first 30 or so minutes of the movie are not as good as the rest, I think. They rely more on "fat humor" (Po) and so-so jokes. Not that any of the first half hour is bad...just that, all of it combined, is a little too cheesy. There aren't really any witty jokes or clever bits to accompany the rest...if there was, this would be a lot better.

However, once the story picks up, it is very good. The fat humor is still used, but its more important to the story, so quite funny; and the cheesy jokes sort of disappear, which is also good.

All in all, this is a really good movie. Not quite 5/5 stars because of the first half hour, but a solid 4/5.

I work in the industry and just love this movie!  Even my tired, jaded old eyes are excited by it!
The story is great fun for people who love Kung Fu movies, but is also told in a way that makes it enjoyable to a broader audience.  It has great humour throughout that's fun and charming without having to go to the vulgar side.

The animation is top notch.  This is my area of expertise, and I just love the animation. The physical believability is very good, and on top of it, the movement has been stylistically well thought out to have interesting texture to the timing and look lively and beautiful.  The acting is very nicely done.  Also, the introduction is in the hand-drawn style.  It's graphically simple, yet sophisticated and powerful.  The end credits also have a strong graphic quality that's just fun to watch.

Other areas in which I'm not totally expert still have importance, and I know what I like.  The sense of design throughout the movie is strong and cohesive.  It's appealing and understandable.  The art direction is wonderful.  Very pretty pictures with good understanding of colour and tonal value that support and enhance the mood of each part of the movie.  You get totally drawn into that world.
The choreography of the fight sequences is beautifully thought out.  It's exciting and entertaining.  Even the more outlandish moves have a ring of truth and believability.

The part of the panda has got to have been written with Jack Black in mind.  Even if that weren't necessarily so, from the writing to the voice acting to the animation performance, the teamwork to get this character to be like this is tight.  His sensibility permeates the character.  And you like him from the start of the movie, which makes it so easy to be pulling for him all the way through.
The rest of the characters in the movie, from the old master tortoise to the adoptive father goose are beautifully done and a joy to watch. The all star cast of voice actors add a dimension of fun without distracting from the story.

Also, the craftsmanship of the DVD and it's case are...  ..well, they're standard, aside from the nice cover art,
but the movie is really great!

YES! Really!

I love everything about this movie: the story, the writing, the animation, the voice acting, the music, the setting: mystical China.

It's got the funny, the adventure, the heart.

Get it. Watch it. You'll love it.

This is a kids' film, with rather grotesque vaudeville antics, cheesy life lessons, and an impossible plot.  Nonetheless, there is absolutely no question that this works.  From the first image of the buffoon Panda, I knew intuitively that I would enjoy this film in the way that a child's mind can:  suspending my disbelief and surrendering myself to the experience, no matter how ridiculous.

Even though it checks all of the boxes:  ancient riddle wisdom, action acrobatics that are as mesmerizing as they are impossible, a deadly adversary that only the best can face, the destiny of dreams, and a training program for novices that transforms their lives both inside and outside.  Of course, there is the plucky neophyte, a most unlikely choice to join the greatest of warriors.  What's more, the established cadre does not want to accept the master's choice of the Panda, taking on a mission to reject and undermine him physically and psychologically.

The uberbad guy escapes and comes to claim his mantle as master.  Meanwhile, the Panda takes his training in spite of the challenges, proving his character for the coming battle.  The process is fun to watch and you believe it.  The buildup in tension is good and there is plenty of comic relief, even in decisive battles.

Warmly recommended.  This is great family entertainment.
Just what my 8 year old wanted. Got it for him for bringing home a good report card. He absolutely loves this movie!

This is a film with truly inventive three dimensional animation and a creative storyline that is full of life lessons for young and old. I was told that KUNG FU PANDA was "very Zen," and it is. It's also fun to watch. It's anthropomorphic animal cast is endearing.

Po (voiced by Jack Black) is "a big, fat panda" from the Valley of Peace, who works in his Dad's noodle shop as a waiter. His Dad (voiced by James Hong) is a goose whose fondest wish is that his son follow him into the family business. Po's Dad is awaiting the glorious day when he can reveal to Po the secret ingredient in his Secret Ingredient Noodle Soup.

Po, for his part, dreams of being a Kung Fu warrior, and idolizes the Furious Five, a group of highly trained warriors taught by Master Shifu, a Red Panda (voiced by Dustin Hoffman). Shifu's own Master, Oogway (voiced by Randall Duk Kim) is a wise old tortoise who warns Shifu that his renegade student Tai Lung (a Snow Leopard voiced by Ian McShane) will be returning to the Valley to exact vengeance against Shifu for having been passed over as the greatest warrior of all time, The Dragon Warrior. Oogway prophesies that the true Dragon Warrior will appear to defeat Tai Lung. Shifu, for his part, has none of the equipoise of Oogway. He is short-tempered and judgemental.

The Furious Five represent each of the major styles of Kung Fu. Tigress (voiced by Angelina Jolie) is their leader. She is egotistical. Monkey (Jackie Chan), Mantis (Seth Rogen), Viper (Lucy Liu), and Crane (David Cross) who round out the group, each have small roles.

Comes the great day when Oogway is to name the Dragon Warrior, and the designate-presumptive, Tigress, is shocked to discover that Oogway picks the totally untrained, physically clumsy Po as The Dragon Warrior. The rest of the Furious Five are nonplussed. Shifu too, has great doubts about Oogway's choice. The group is rude to Po and mock him at every opportunity until Oogway commands Shifu to train Po. The secret to Po's training is contained in the mysterious Dragon Scroll, which only the Dragon Warrior may have, and which Tai Lung covets.

The animated action sequences are complex and realistic, breaking new ground in animation. The film is very visually appealing and captures a sense of a stylized Classical China beautifully. It is the storyline that truly shines, though, as the characters learn not to judge one's skills, talent and abilities---whether ally or  opponent or oneself---by appearances alone.

In the same vein as THE KARATE KID, KUNG FU PANDA is a great movie for everybody of any age.
my son was asking me to get it for him and i don feel disapointed. wonderfull movie.

I'll admit that I usually shy away from films that seem to be showered in hype.  I like to march to the beat of my own drum when it comes to discovering an under-appreciated gem and yet still found myself intrigued by the glowing opinions surrounding DreamWorks' Kung Fu Panda.  Sure Jack Black was decent in Shark Tale and Eastern Philosophy would probably naturally lend itself to the notion of martial arts masters who just so happen to be adorable talking animals but come on! It can't be that great, right?  Wrong!

Until picking up Kung Fu Panda, I was pretty thoroughly convinced that aside from Shrek, DreamWorks was doomed to play second fiddle to Pixar in the world of computer generated animated feature films.  Kung Fu Panda manages to combine story originality, magnificent visuals and genuine humor so flawlessly that it is much to Pixar's detriment that they have nothing to offer in terms of competition.

KFP tells the tale of Po (Jack Black); a panda that works in a noodle restaurant owned by his father Mr. Ping (James Hong), who just so happens to be a goose. Po is a kung fu fanatic with secret dreams of becoming a great master in the discipline despite no prior training and a body style that favors weight and clumsiness.

The tortoise Master Oogway (played brilliantly by Randall Duk Kim) has a premonition that the evil snow leopard Tai Lung (Ian McShane), the former student of his own protg, Master Shifu (Dustin Hoffman), will escape from prison and return to threaten the Valley of Peace.

Oogway orders a formal ceremony to choose the Dragon Warrior, a supreme master of kung fu and the one who can defeat the lethal Tai Lung should the premonition come to pass. It is assumed that one of the Furious Five: Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Monkey (Jackie Chan), Mantis (Seth Rogen), Viper (Lucy Liu), and Crane (David Cross) will be chosen for this honor.

Po, in attempt to simply spectate the event, finds himself smack dab in the middle of the ceremony. Oogway, surprised by the panda's sudden appearance, designates him the Dragon Warrior and hence Po is immediately in way over his head.

It's tough to come up with anything new to add to a film that has already been so thoroughly praised since its inception but that's no excuse for me to refrain from trying.  I was quite dazzled with Kung Fu Panda's solid homages to classic kung fu movies while simultaneously brining an original and attention-worthy story to the table.  Pacing, plot structure, and character development are all top notch through and through and the humor, which is often so natural as to appear nearly unintentional, is the icing on the proverbial cake.

It is often suggested that DreamWorks tends to release in quantity what Pixar does in quality but every once in a while a DreamWorks production manages to raise the bar for all of the other studios to attempt to follow.  The stars aligned a decade ago when Shrek was released and it would seem the studio has managed to find that magic once again in Kung Fu Panda.

A funny tale of misfit adventure showing Po who is torn between the family responsibility of doing the right thing by his adopted father who owns a meager noodle shop and his dream of wanting to be a real Kung Fu warrior.  This movies is also a timeless treasure in our home and is loved by all!
this movie is hilarious, my husband and i are in our 50's and it is awesome...the grandkids also love it.
This was a birthday request and the child just loves this video--as does all his friends.

I absolutely love this movie. IT takes me back to many of the old Kung-fu movies I wish Hollywood still made.
The story follows Po (Jack Black). A young goofy Panda who works in a soup kitchen by his father side. His father eagerly awaits the day he will take over the soup kitchen, but Po has other dreams. Po wishes to one day become the strongest Kung-fu warrior there ever was and fight along the noctorious Furious Five.

I won't say more because I don't want to give away too much, but this is definately one of the best animated movies I've seen since the Incredibles. The cinemagraphy for the action scenes in this movie are intense and had me on the edge of my seat. There was one scene in particular I found myself just sitting and looking at in awe from just how brilliant it was. There was also a training segment that was just breathtaking in its visual style. Its very reminiscent of old Bruce Lee, Jet Li, and Jackie Chan movies. The movie itself looks extremely good. The lighting and detail made it fun to look at. I also found it clever that the all the furious Five are basically chosen and named after martial art styles. Don't even get me started on the main villian. He was definatly one of the best things about the movie. He was brutal, somewhat missunderstood because he was raised in a way that lead to his fall, almost unstoppable, and just powerful.  The story is actually kind of dark later on, but holds a message to it that I would expect in a martial arts movie like this.

 Even though I'm giving this 5 stars there is one thing in particular I didn't like. The Furious Five are voiced by Jackie Chan, Angelina Jolie, and other very familiar actors, but they are barely given any dialogue in the movie. Not only that they didn't really go too deeply into the characters of the Furious Five. I know theres a second bonus dvd that they were selling in Walmart with the movie (I actually own both) that tells thier backstory, but I would have still loved if thier characters were given more time on screen. If they make a sequal, and I really hope they do, I wish they would flesh out thier characters a little more.

 Kung-fu panda I admit won't be for everyone, expecially those who aren't into kungfu action films or overprotective parents who think anything that isn't barney level is too violent for kids. Kung-Fu Panda is a great homage to the action movies I love. Its original, fun, and just plain awesome. Its worth a buy for both children and adults to enjoy.

I bought the film for my young nephews and I found myself really enjoying it. Jack Black was hilarious as Po the misfit panda who always wanted to learn Kung Fu and finally gets his chance which atarts out as disaster then he turns into a dragon master. I liked it as an adult, I think it's just like Beverly Hills Ninja only animated.
Kung Fu Panda is definitely in the top bracket of movies based on animals practicing martial arts.  It would probably be the best, but the Ninja Turtles are tough competition.

Nothing ground breaking or suspenseful about the main story line, it is very typical there.

Graphics, effects, while great is also nothing that blows your mind away.

Still, it is a load of fun, witty, and incorporates enough of the traditional Chinese Kung-fu mystique to make it interesting even for fans well aware of Chinese martial arts literature.

But really, you don't watch this movie to find something that you couldn't find watching other movies - it's simply well-crafted and not lacking.
I love this movie even more than my kids do.  Plus, how can you go wrong with a Jack Black movie?

Dreamworks Animation's "Kung Fu Panda" will most likely be claimed as one of their classics. If not, then it should be. This film which stars Jack Black as Po (the panda) centers on a big fat Panda with hopes of being a master in Kung Fu, yes a panda and yes kung fu, you can't make this stuff up. He dreams of working with Master Shifu (Dustin Hoffman)and the furious five -Tigress(Angelina Jolie), Viper(Lucy Lu), Monkey(Jackie Chan), Mantis(Seth Rogen), and Crane (David Cross). When Master Oogway(Randall Duk Kim) -a very spiritual and wise turtle- declares Po as the Dragon Warrior, Shifu and the furious five grow beyond angry that they not only have to train Po in Kung Fu but train him to defeat the legendary Tai Ling(Iam McShane)- the greatest, most powerful tiger there is. Can Po rise up and defeat Tai Ling or will Po, his family and the rest of the town suffer from the loss and destruction that Tai Ling will cause?

"Kung Fu Panda" is definitely up there with one of my favorite animated movies. It's clever, unique, and funny. Jack Black is a delight, the audience just wants to root for him from the first second he appears on screen. He's fun and goofy and it's great to see his personality shine through an animated panda bear with just his voice. Dustin Hoffman and the furious five are all individually great in their animal fighting roles.

The story line is very original and packed with really great laughs. I love how they slow down certain kung fu parts to make it more dramatic but it winds up just being funny. I also love that Po's dad is a bird that makes noodles.

In my opinion I think this movie is awesome. It is wonderful for both children and adults. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys animated fun comedies, movies with a lot of heart and a wonderful message to send to children of all ages.

If you saw "Kung Fu Panda" please share your opinion! Just don't give away too much, we don't want to ruin it for anyone! Also, I hear they are making a sequel how do you feel about that??

This movie by far is one of my favorite movies besides Toy Story i think this movie was really funny Jack Black is Hilarious as Po the panda great lines and every part was just so funny my family loved it and all the kids tht come over and if you are a babysitter you should put this movie its very entertaining for all ages i Love the scene were Tai Long escapes from prison really cool! also how Master shifu trains Po the cast was great! i cant wait for the next Kung fu panda which is coming out next year Kung Fu Panda the kaboom of doom said to be out may 2011.

Alright guys, it's official- animation delivers the laughs better than *any* other style of comedy.  This includes stand up routines, sitcoms with live studio audiences, or just your uncle Bob telling you a joke during a family visit.  Kung Fu Panda absolutely rules, and the animation is one of the main reasons why.

I've actually wanted to watch Kung Fu Panda for quite a while now.  I finally got the chance to watch it this afternoon.  It certainly lived up to all the hype it received a couple years ago.

What makes it so enjoyable is the fact that the laughs aren't the only exciting thing about Kung Fu Panda- it's the outrageous and zanny action segments that really elevate this film to a level of untouchable greatness.  We're talking a LOT of animated action here, folks.

The storyline is about a panda bear that's severely out of shape but dreams about becoming the ultimate master of kung fu fighting.

Eventually he's chosen to be given such a chance, with lots of special attention and guidance from his master (along with other friends).  Unfortunately his laziness constantly prevents him from ever reaching his dream... until a really evil wild cat comes into the equation and pretty much forces the panda bear to stand up and fight.

I don't know what's most awesome about Kung Fu Panda- the exciting action and fighting segments, the actual humor and jokes involving all the animated animals communicating with each other, or just the brilliantly executed animation frames themselves.

One thing's for sure- you simply MUST watch this movie.  Adults and children alike must watch it.  You'll be laughing hard and heavy, I guarantee it!

What a fun movie. The story is outstanding and the animation is wonderful. The cast of voice actors do a fantastic job of embracing their characters and advancing the storyline through deliciously-quotable dialog. For younger viewers, the movie is captivating and compelling while higher-level jokes and cultural references abound for the benefit of adults. Both touching and humorous, this is a great example of a creative and interesting movie perfect for family and friends of all ages.

Kung Fu Panda is a very fun animated movie that I enjoy and my kids love. Po (nicely voiced by Jack Black) is an affable but somewhat overweight Panda that dreams of becoming a Kung Fu Master. Sadly, his lot in life seems to be making and selling noodles for his father (he was adopted) and all of the Kung Fu glory reserved for the "Furious Five" (who even have a line of action figures). All of that changes when chance lands him in the roll of the "Dragon Warrior" and his Kung Fu training begins in earnest... just in time to face the powerful escaped villainous snow leopard, Tai Lung (Ian McShane).

Like most martial arts movies, there is significant violence but it is mostly of the slapstick cartoon variety. There is a very positive message for kids that comes through loud and clear, don't judge people based on looks and preconceptions.

The animation is good and the voice acting is enjoyable with Dustin Hoffman, Angelina Jolie, Jackie Chan, Seth Rogan, David Cross, Lucy Liu and.

Highly Recommended!

CFH

Hadn't seen this until we saw it in blu-ray. It sure is gorgeous, and intelligent to boot, easily in the pantheon with the Incredibles, Up, Wall-E, and a few other recent masterpieces of animation.

Funny cute animation. Bought this for a girl friend and loved it. Jack Black is hilarious and the movie doesn't get boring!

I love the crap out of this movie. It's hilarious, the animation is beautiful and it takes everything you'd like from new and old Kung Fu movies to make stunning and action packed fight scenes. The voice talent is great too, though of course Jack Black being the most over the top character in this movie stands out the most. There's a nice underlying message about learning to love one's self that I thought was touching. Good for kids AND adults. A must for any kung fu or animation lover. Go buy it nao.

Finally!!! An animation about kung fu!! It was about time!
With an influx of animation films to choose from this one was definitely a great find.  I think animation should be fun.  Animations should also have characters do 'stuff' that live characters cannot.  Kung Fu Panda has covered them all with plenty of laugh-out-loud moments with some beautifully exaggerated fight scenes. :)  Jack Black brought his distinct comedic style and gave this Panda character and adorable-ness as well as the agility deserving of a kung fu master.  I grew up in Hong Kong watching kung fu movies as a part of my regular TV routine and this movie did fantastically in covering the basics of the authentic kung fu film: The underdog who no one believes in, comes through and surprises everyone.  There's the serious, yet wise kung fu master.  And then there's the wiser kung fu master above him.  And of course the funny supporting cast.  Perfect.  One can never watch enough movies about believing in oneself, can one?  So, go out and have some fun!  Watch this!

This was a good kids movie, it didn't keep the attention of my 2 year old as much as other movies, but I really enjoyed the story and the humor of the movie.  I do think this movie is worthy of a sequel and may have the following similar to Sherk, so I think it is worthy of another storyline.

I read all the other reviews with lots of details and insights. They were great!

Originally, I was NOT going to watch this movie - it seemed hokey from the previews.
It happened to be on HBO.
I watched it.
I'm HOOKED!!!!

I loved each and every bit of it!

I memorized dialog ("Yesterday is history, Tomorrow is a mystery, but Today is a gift - that is why it is called the 'present'.")

I sing the song (a re-make of the classic "Kung Fu Fighting" with Jack Black chiming in in the background).

I glance the online TV guide to see when it is on HBO or Cinemax.

It was only AFTER I watched it for the first time that I realized that one of the Directors (Mark Osborne) is the brother of one of my classmates from high school (Kent Osborne - who also adds voice talent to the movie). How cool is that?! Someone I actually knew created one of my more favorite movies!!

What I TRULY appreciate about this movie is that it didn't try to be "politically correct" in the portrayal of the lives of the villagers. I really felt like I was NOT being "talked at" during this movie.

What am I trying to say, here?

It felt like if I could visit this 'place' in real life, that it would look and function exactly like it does in this film. Like nothing was FAKE. Almost like I was actually GLIMPSING a "real" moment in time.

This DVD sits proudly on our DVD shelf, but has no dust on the cover. It is watched over and over again.

I can't wait for a sequel ... ! (yay!)

And if either of the Osborne's are reading ... THANK YOU! (from a HCHS alum!)
I bought this movie for my grandson and was pleasantly surprised.  It's great for a two year old and adults as well.
This is one of our all-time favorite films!  It's something you will want to watch over and over and each time you will notice details that you hadn't before.

Most of the elements of this movie are done well, with one piece done REALLY well.  The storyline is frankly a little bland - Panda, working in dad's noodle shop, dreams of being a Kung-fu master.  When prophesy says that the more-or-less villainous Tai-Lung may escape from prison, Master Oogway decides to appoint a "Dragon Warrior" from amongst "The Five" masters:  Tigress, Monkey, Crane, Mantis (as in, praying), and Viper.  Inevitably Panda gets in the way of Oogway's pointing finger, and we follow Panda's journey in Kung Fu land.

The storyline may not be noteworthy but the rest of the movie more than makes up for it.  Panda (Jack Black) and his Kung-Fu teacher Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) lead the movie and each are outstanding.  When the mysticism of Kung Fu begins to soar a little out of bounds, Black's blue-collar approach to Panda brings it back down to earth.  Panda, a slobbering fan of "The Five", is overwhelmed simply to be in their presence ("You're all much bigger than your action figures.  Except for you, Master Mantis").  The dialogue is well written and very funny and entertaining.

Where this movie shines is in the visuals.  For some inexplicable reason, Dreamworks just pulled out ALL the stops on the animation work and this movie is simply gorgeous.  The colors are beautiful, the mountain scenery is stunning, the stars at night, the fog, sunrise, etc etc...

The animation peaks in the rendering of Tai Lung, the sort-of villain.  Tai Lung is depicted as an utterly magnificent snow leopard, and when he's on-screen in all his massive glory he simply OWNS the movie.  His escape from the inescapable prison is by far the most exciting action scene in the movie, too bad it comes near the beginning.  I can't help but wish they'd build an entire movie solely around this magnificent creature (it's hard to even mention him without using the word "magnificent").

If you own a 19-inch 4:3 television, you may find this movie entertaining at most.  If you're fortunate to have a full home theater setup with blu-ray you'll be stunned.  The third or fourth time you watch it you may even be tempted to turn the sound down, pop in some head music instead, and just soar with the visuals.  I only wish this movie were a painting so I could hang it on my wall.

I had not seen this movie in the theaters but I had heard rave reviews about it. So I snagged this one on sale. The movie is hilarious and very entertaining and the visuals only make this movie that much better. Watching this on full 1080p through my ps3 is just amazing. These newer animations on Blu Ray just look amazing. I will be purchasing anything made by pixar and or disney, not only because they look spectacular but they are usually quite entertaining.

What do you get when you combine state of the art CGI, some of the best actors in Hollywood, and animals performing kung fu? One of the year's best movies. Kung Fu Panda was widely loved by critics and fans during its theatrical release, and for good reason.

The movie centers around Po the panda, and his journey of self discovery. Po (Jack Black) is the (adopted) son of a noodle maker (played by the legendary James Hong), and his father wants nothing more than for Po to follow in the family footsteps of running the noodle shop. Unfortunately, Po has dreams of more kung fu-y things; his idols aren't chefs and cooks, but the legendary Furious Five.

When he hears that kung fu teacher Shifu (Dustin Hoffman) is going to hold trials to find out which of the Furious Five are the Dragon Warrior who is destined to save the village from the evil Tai Lung, Po drops everything, disrespects his father's wishes, and sneaks off to witness the trials. After a series of unfortunate events culminating in a firework powered rocket chair, Po becomes crowned the Dragon Warrior, and begins to learn kung fu in order to fulfill his destiny.

While a fairly clich tale at its core, Kung Fu Panda nevertheless delights for a multitude of reasons. Whether it's the humorous dialog, the masterful voice acting by the stars (including Angelina Jolie, Jackie Chan, David Cross, Lucy Liu, and Seth Rogen), or the ultimate lesson that anyone can achieve anything if they try hard enough, it's impossible not to love the movie. Not since Shrek has a non-Pixar animated film been this magnificent, and not since the Disney films of the early 90s has an animated movie managed to not only entertain children and adults, but also teach important lessons that are valuable to people of all ages, backgrounds, and lifestyles.

Visually and audibly, Kung Fu Panda is far superior on Blu-Ray than DVD, but unlike many modern movies the studio didn't seem to hold back from the traditional DVD release, and the picture looks slightly better than Pixar's Ratatouille and Cars.

To reward DVD purchasers, the DVD comes packed with a special additional 30 minute feature revolving around the Furious Five. In this extra take, Po and Shifu return to the martial arts temple in order to train a group of young rabbits. In over his head, Po resorts to teaching them the five moralities of kung fu by explaining how each of the Furious Five (Crane, Monkey, Viper, Tigress, and Mantis) came to be who they were. Unlike the movie, The Secrets of the Furious Five is created with watercolor inspired Asian art, much like the film's opening credits.

Unfortunately, only David Cross reprises his role from the movie for the Furious Five. (Black and Hoffman both return as Po and Shifu, though.) The other four are noticeably absent, although Monkey's is handled quite brilliantly with Jaycee Chan (Jackie Chan's son) playing him. Who better to play a young version of Jackie Chan's character than Jackie's own son? It's disappointing to not get his voice back for more, but it's a smart decision that I felt paid off.

Outside of the extra separate disc feature, the features packed on the Kung Fu Panda disc itself are entertaining enough, but nothing stands out as extraordinary. The thirteen minute "Meet the Cast" feature is the most worthwhile of the bunch, as it shows a lot of the stars on the set and gets their take on what it's like to record voices in such an unusual picture. (Fun fact: I didn't notice Seth Rogen was Mantis until I watched this after the movie. Dude's in EVERYTHING these days!)

Despite the lack of meaningful extras other than the Secrets of the Furious Five and Meet the Cast, Kung Fu Panda is still a must-own on whatever format you're capable of playing. If you own a blu-ray player, buy it on BR. If you own a DVD player, buy it on DVD. It's a family movie that truly is fun for the whole family - even if your family has no one under the age of 20. Buy it, watch it, love it, and be reminded of the time when people other than Pixar made classic animated films.
Not a Jack Black fan, but this was a fun movie for the kids, and even us grownups didn't mind watching it a few times.

A horrible storyline can spoil even the best of films.
American film-makers have this neverending love for stereotyped underdog stories with the brave character who finds his true self and achieves success despite most unpromising circumstances. I suppose it is a manifestation of a stereotyped image of the American dream, this feeding the average viewer with the idea that anyone can have a dream an make a success out of it.
This underdog storyline can be sometimes exploited with originality and effectiveness (take Hercules and Mulan, to remain to cartoons) but it can also be a tricky path to choose as it is fully demonstrated here.

That animation is excellent (and yet computer tricks are a little TOO evident and mechanical looking) and rhythm serrated, that voice-acting is professional and funny turns out not to be enough.
This movie is not good, not even for children actually, not because of any improper adult content but because the ethics conveyed here are simply not healthy for a kid.

I saw it and wondered what the academy was smoking and why they weren't willing to share. Did I seriously miss something with this movie? First of all the movie was not funny. I don't about the movie going masses, but Jack Black needed to try and learn how to diversify is acting. I really thought that after his role in King Kong he would have gone on to do some great work. Instead we him doing the exact same thing in every movie he makes. My other problem was the cast. You would have guessed that Jackie Chan was in this movie? I once thought that Disney had finally gotten knocked off the pedistil as the number one maker of animated films. Nowadays I realize I may be wrong. You have to see who wants to bring a good film to the masses and who just wants to make the big bucks. It really is a numbers game when it comes down to it.
First Pixar Toy Story 1995 First DreamWorks Antz 1997
Pixar: 10 soon to be 11 with Toy Story 3  Dreamworks: 15 Soon to be 17 with How To Train Your Dragon and Oobermind
How many won oscars? so far it's Disney 4 and Dreamworks 2

I guess Disney still has the magic and for the record Up was amazing!

One of the best new family movies to come out in the last few years.

As voiced by funnyman Jack Black, Po is just your average Chinese panda with dreams of one day becoming a world-class kung fu fighter (isn`t that what all pandas living in China aspire to be?).  When he's chosen by The Master to become the new Dragon Warrior, a position that brings virtually unlimited power to the individual who holds it, Po is thrown into round-the-clock training sessions to help groom him for the role - kind of like Eliza Doolittle on steroids.

The plot of "Kung Fu Panda" - with its echoes of "The Karate Kid" and even of "Star Wars" in its portrayal of teacher/pupil relationships - is fairly derivative in nature and lacks the kind of  strong secondary characters we`ve come to expect from computer-animated  films (no slam intended on the voiceover work by Dustin Hoffman, Ian McShane, Angelina Jolie, Lucy Liu, Seth Rogen and Jackie Chan).

Still, there is sufficient energy, wit and visual inventiveness in the movie to captivate the little ones while keeping the rest of us from actively storming the box office and demanding our money back.  This is most definitely not one of the "great ones," as animated features go, but it is short and pleasant enough to at least earn it a spot in the recommended column.
Funny, great movie, you can watch it many times and you will enjoy it everytime. Everyone in the family enjoy it. It is great movie from the content to the music. Wonderful!

"Kung Fu Panda" is one of the more pleasant surprises to come out of the Hollywood animated film machine these days.  While the Pixar movies are virtual locks for greatness, the rest of the genre has become rather tired, with big name stars lining up for movies designed for max box office appeal rather than great storytelling.

So the non-Pixar test these days is, are we watching something more akin to "Shrek," or closer to "Shrek the Third"?

"KFP" is, thank goodness, right up there with "Shrek" in the pantheon of enjoyable animated films not produced by Pixar.  Jack Black is the perfect choice to play Po, the panda seemingly consigned by fate and fat to sell noodles the rest of his life.  But Po's destiny is to be something else- the Dragon Warrior, who shall bring peace to all.

Black's comedic timing is on display as he gets virtually all the great lines in this movie, although Dustin Hoffman does yeoman's work as his kung fu mentor, Master Shifu.  This movie essentially wastes other big names who were cast for no apparent reason, as they lend very little to the story:  Angelina Jolie, Seth Rogan, Lucy Liu, David Cross and Jackie Chan lend their voices to the Furious Five (a collection of kung fu warriors), but none of these fine actors does anything significant.  Ian MacShane plays the villain as only he can, but in large part this is Black's and Hoffman's show.

Very family friendly, with more than a few "fat jokes" thrown in (but these are more funny than caustic).  Excellent animation and solid storytelling throughout - this is a very good family film.
Not a bad movie but no where near as good as the movie "Cars". I wouldn't have wanted to pay for 5-6 kids to see it at the movie theater.

I am no prude but this film is clearly not appropriate for anyone that young.  The violence was extreme and vicious, even by adult standards.  It should have been advertised as such.

More than a remake, this DreamWorks animated movie is an evident ripoff of the late Chris Farley's 1997 comedy; the more so because no one admits it is!. Pillage includes the movie's premise (Big Fat Klutz rises from Class Embarrassment to to Top Martial Arts Master), several key scenes, the theme song (you guessed it -"Kung Fu Fighting"), and entire lines, starting with Farley's classic "That's AWWWWESOME!!!", looted as the panda's mantra.

Having said that, Kung Fu Panda is by far a much better film. In fact, it's a great film; the kind of film I wish I'd seen when I was a boy. Back then, us chubby kids were not the rule but the exception, and it seemed our only reason in life was to bear with a grin countless fat jokes and ridicule from peers and teachers (if you think Kubrick dreamt up all the abuse you hear in Full Metal Jacket, you weren't born before 1980). A fat kid was not only considered glutton but stupid, since you couldn't do whatever it was the other kids did. You either found yourself something to be good at, or you cried yourself to sleep. Fortunately for me, I found drawing, and upon it I developed my professional success. Unfortunately for me, I also developed diabetes.

Today, obese kids are not the class fatsos but a global pandemia. Kung Fu Panda shows these kids they may not be the ideal, but they're certainly no damaged goods; in fact, they can excel to whatever their will takes them if they learn discipline, sacrifice, compassion, patience, toil and respect. Not a bad message to get across, specially when most "cool"movies only promote sex, guns and foul language.

Plus, the movie itself is a marvel to look at. Not only its animation, which is superb, but the artistic concept behind it, for one not only sees funny characters kicking butt, one sees them as part of entire Chinese watercolors come to life in a universe where every background has a life of its own, and no detail is overlooked. I haven't seen an animated film of such graphic beauty since 101 Dalmatians, nearly fifty years ago.

This was a nice movie with likable characters but, frankly, I didn't find it anything memorable. Yes, it was beautiful artwork but I read where it was the most beautiful animation ever put on screen, and I didn't find it lived up to that.

I guess my expectations were sky high, which made it almost impossible to meet. The story could have used more laughs, too. I think that was the main thing that slightly disappointed me: the humor was mild, not laugh-out-loud funny.

Having said all that, it was enjoyable and it will put numerous smiles on your face as you watch it. I guess "pleasant," "agreeable," "warm," etc., would be better words to describe the film. It is pretty, too, especially on Blu-Ray. I imagine this looked awesome on IMAX in the theater.

Jack Black does a nice job of voicing the main character, "Po," the panda that surprised everyone, including himself, on what he could achieve if he set his mind to it. That's another plus for the film: nice messages.

Kids should like this more than adults but grownups will enjoy it, too.

ooo wow, Jack black can do anything. He is absolutely amazing in this. Great story and awesome plot. the action is off the hook awesome, and boy does it look awesome in Blu. That fat Panda kicks butt and earns my respect and he will yours too.

There are plenty of reviews here about the movie itself, so I'll just limit my comments to the quality of this movie in Blu-Ray. To date this is the most astonishing Blu-Ray movie I've seen. The detail is astounding, you can see each blade of grass and tree leaf in full hi-def glory and they are actually moving in the wind! Every texture on every surface was lovingly modeled by the animation team and show up in crisp, clear detail on our 52" Bravia. The closer you get to the TV the more detail you see, it's really quite amazing. I watched it at home the first time with my older daughter and the entire movie we were saying things like "look at the texture on his clothes!" "Look at the moss growing on the rocks!" We barely noticed the dialog because we were so floored by the incredible visuals! We typically rent movies, but this particular one was a must-own just to show visitors to our home what Blu-Ray and hi-def TVs are all about. Plus as others here have said it's a great movie for kids and adults alike, and that's icing on this glorious 1080p cake :-)

Animated films are right up my alley. I enjoy the camaraderie, spirit, and stick-to-itiveness that embody the characters the majority of the time. Bundle that with pitch perfect comedic timing and hijinks, it proves the recipe for a winner.

Po (Jack Black) is a giant panda who dreams of being the most "awesomely awesome" Kung-Fu master that ever walked the planet. Too bad for him he works in his father's (who happens to be a goose-classic) noodle shop. His heroes are the Furious Five: Mantis (Seth Rogen), Monkey (Jackie Chan), Viper (Lucy Liu), Crane (David Cross), and Tigress (Angelina Jolie). Their leader is Master Shifu (which is "master" in Chinese, so they're saying "master master" during the whole film, more laughter) and his master is Master Oogway (Randall Duk Kim). The enemy of this motley crew is the leopard Tai Lung (Ian McShane), Shifu's adopted protg.

In a twist of fate at the ceremony to name the Chosen One, Po literally falls into that role. Uncoordinated, forever hungry, and completely clueless to the intricacies of Kung-Fu, he manages to fit in with the gang except for Tigress and Shifu (a fall-out of my seat moment happened when Mantis was giving Po acupuncture and tweaked a facial nerve).

The ultimate showdown between Po and Tai Lung is fantastic. The action sequences (with "Matrix" slowdowns and stop-motion) were breathtaking (along with the accompanying backdrops). This is a great film, destined to join the hierarchy of great animated classics of the past. 4.5 stars!
Any genXer who was around watching Sat morning kung-fu marathons will laugh at this animated spoof on ku-fu action movies.  Kids will love the slapstick actions of the hero and his friends.
A good animated movie that has plenty of action and no hidden agendas. Both adults and kids enjoyed this movie.

Everyone has awesome talents and abilities if they look at themselves closely and accept who they are. Jack Black was perfect as the Panda and the animation reflected his animated personality. I laughed so hard tears came to my eyes during this movie, especially during the final fight scene. I've watched that over and over, laughed every time.

The movie is funny and entertaining. A good movie for everyone to watch.

Being a Hong Kong Chinese over 40 who loves anime and Kung Fu much, you can bet I had watched hundreds of movies of this genre, primarily from Japanese. However, I must say that this may be the best mix of everything. The animals are cute. The story is old fashioned yet acceptably interesting to all ages. The art is fantastic that every screen shot can be taken as a wallpaper. The CG is brilliant. The choreography (the fighting) is excellent. I can hardly pick a significant shortcoming of it. I watched it together with my wife and she, not a lover of anime or Kung Fu movie at all, did love it and laugh frequently. Definitely a good entertainment after a decent meal at home. Recommended!

The only criticism I have is that this otherwise stellar Blu-ray is missing the Furious Five short feature. This would have made the high def disc complete.

Great movie, fantastic image and audio. 4 1/2 stars.

So who would win in a fight? Kung Fu Panda (Po) or Wall-E? Which movie is better? Let's break it down in pro boxing's real world 8-point-must system. The fight for the better movie (6 Rounds): Wall-E story: 10 Kung Fu Panda story: 9 Wall-E voice acting talent: 8 Kung Fu Panda voice acting talent: 10 Wall-E action: 9 Kung Fu Panda action: 10 Wall-E family fun factor: 9 Kung Fu Panda family fun factor: 10 Wall-E "I wanna see it again" factor: 9 Kung Fu Panda "I wanna see it again" factor: 10 Wall-E DVD extras: 9 Kung Fu Panda DVD extras: 10 Unanimous decision: Wall-E 54 Kung Fu Panda 59 Better Movie: Kung Fu Panda Now if Wall-E and Po had to fight for the title, it would probably go something like this: Po comes right out swinging and kicking. Wall-E immediately looks broken. Po belly-slams Wall-E and one of Wall-E's eye-lenses pops loose. When I started this movie, I expected a simple children's film with cardboard characters and half-rate animation. Instead, I was pleasantly surprised on most counts.

I don't know why people ranked this film's animation below Pixar's. Character designs are well done and colors are on the mark. Just the first section of Kung Fu Panda has a wonderfully stylized dream sequence full of delightful color, movement, and humor. Fight sequences are exciting and entertaining -- bizarre, really, when you realize you're looking at a bunch of anthropomorphic animals doing impossible things (impossible things that look strangely possible!). Emotion is effortlessly imparted on each character's face -- even through such small things as their eyes and simple shifts in their postures. There are many frames in this movie that could be turned into a picture on the wall (Oogway's ascension, the Tigress leaping past the moon). Face it -- you can't give Pixar all the credit in the animation biz.

The humor is varied between jokes at Po's expense to slapstick. It's juvenile humor, to be sure; the kiddos will adore it, but it's unconventional enough to pull a chuckle or two out of adults. Po training with dumplings was nothing short of a laugh a minute.

The characters themselves are actually a bit more complex than what I expected. Po is a sweet, good-natured protagonist who I really rooted for; Jack Black does an excellent job as his voice actor. The Master Shi-Fu (voiced by Hoffman) has a surprising past that left a tear in my eye, as does villain Tai Lun. The Furious Five are the only rather "flat" characters, only because they have less screen time.

The downside is the very formulaic story, which rushes forward at the speed of a bullet train, and its simple, fortune-cookie Chinese philosophy. There's nothing wrong with it, per se; but it's just not that striking and it's nothing you haven't heard before. It's ultimately what makes this film forgettable afterward.

This film is a fast-paced, enjoyable diversion that should be fun for kids and adults alike. Just don't expect to come back to it over and over unless you're below the age of 10.
